anchors: What factors must be altered during testing to draw the calibration curves for a pump?
positives: The rotation speed of a pump is a variable quantity. The pump calibration curves can only be drawn after obtaining data resulting from tests. Such tests are executed by varying the impeller diameter (impeller trimming) and the hydraulic resistances at the discharge, in order to obtain the properties required by engine system.

anchors: What must the power delivered at the turbine shaft equal to maintain a proper energy balance in the system?
positives: The volume flow rate of the propellants to either a gas generator or a pre-burner also needs calibration. The power balance requires the power delivered at the turbine shaft to be equal to the sum of the power needed to drive the pumps and the power losses in the bearings, seals, etc.

anchors: What known and assumed quantities are used to determine the requirements for pump head rise and flow rates in a turbo-pump system?
positives: Ina system balance of a turbo-pump at the initial point of design, known quantities (such as engine type, pressure in the thrust chamber, expansion area ratio in the nozzle, oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio, and thrust) are combined with assumed quantities (such as pump efficiencies, turbine efficiencies, turbine pressure ratio, turbine inlet temperature, and various indicators of engine performance), in order to predict the requirements relating to the pump head rise, the pump flow rate, and the turbine flow rate.

anchors: What is equated to the total power absorption in the process of balancing power delivered to the turbine shaft?
positives: In making this balance, the power delivered to the turbine shaft is equated to all the sources of power absorption, as has been shown above..

anchors: Why is it essential to evaluate the performance of pumps and turbines during the design process of a propulsion system?
positives: A system balance of a turbo-pump is also necessary at the final point of design. This is because refinements and changes, which may be made in the detailed design of a rocket engine, can affect the turbo-pump operation. For example, during the development of the engine of the MA-5 sustainer, the efficiencies of the pumps and of the turbine were found, when tested, below the initial values assumed for them in the design balance of the engine system.

anchors: What adjustments were necessary to enhance the turbine drive pressure from the gas generator for the engine to achieve designated thrust capacities?
positives: This fact required changes to increase the 4.8 Heads and Mass Flow Rates of Pumps 301 value of the turbine drive pressure available from the gas generator, in order for the engine to meet its rated thrust values..

anchors: How can off-design operating conditions affect the performance and reliability of a turbo-pump in a rocket engine?
positives: An off-design operating condition of a turbo-pump may be more demanding for a particular component than the nominal design condition. Consequently, the whole operating range of a rocket engine is to be considered carefully. Otherwise, a pump which operates satisfactorily in design conditions may perform unsatisfactorily or even fail in off-design conditions.

anchors: What factors must be considered to establish the complete operational limits of a turbo-pump beyond the planned operational range?
positives: In order to define the actual operating range of a turbo-pump, it is necessary to determine the planned operating range. Then, a system balance including the predicted operating characteristics of the turbo-pump is used to determine the whole range of operation over the planned engine throttling and the variation of the oxidiser- to-fuel mixture ratio. For this purpose, it is necessary to take account not only of the ordinary variations in the operating conditions, but also of the variations due to manufacturing tolerances.

anchors: What types of tolerances must be estimated for hydraulic resistance in components of liquid-propellant engines?
positives: This requires the availability of data on known tolerances of components from existing liquid-propellant engines. These data are used to esti- mate tolerances on hydraulic resistance of lines, valves, and passage channels of the coolant in the nozzle, tolerances on the head rise/flow rate and efficiency/flow rate curves of the pump, etc..

anchors: How are the effects of component tolerances evaluated in a Gaussian distribution framework for an engine system?
positives: The tolerances on all the components are assumed to have a Gaussian distribution. The effects of these tolerances are treated statistically, by taking the square root of the sum of the squares of the effects of all the components. The effect of each component is determined either by performing an engine balance assuming that the given component is at one of the extreme points of its range of tolerance, or by linearising the equations which govern the engine system in order to determine the influence coefficients for each of the components considered..

anchors: What components can influence the discharge pressure of a turbo-pump in rocket engine design?
positives: The control points used for regulating the thrust and the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio can affect the discharge pressure of the turbo-pump and therefore its system design. Either calibration orifices or a pressure regulator have been used to control either the gas flow rate from the gas generator to the turbine or the oxidiser flow rate to the gas generator. For the J-2, F-1, and H-1 rocket engines, calibration orifices have been used in the turbine-gas generator lines to set the power level.

anchors: What method is utilized in the RL10 engine to manage turbine power using heated hydrogen?
positives: For the RL10 engine, heated fuel (hydrogen) has been used to control the turbine power. For this purpose, the fuel was heated by passing through the cooling jacket of the thrust chamber before being ducted to the turbine through a control system which sensed the thrust chamber pressure and adjusted a turbine bypass valve. By contrast, the MA-5 and MB-S rocket engines used a pressure regulator to control the flow of the oxidiser to the gas generator..

anchors: How can the mixture ratio of oxidiser and fuel be regulated in rocket engines?
positives: The control of the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio has been obtained by using either the main propellant valves or a valve controlling the bypass of a propellant around its pump. The engine of the MA-5 sustainer used the control of the main propellant valves, whereas the J-2 engine used a control valve around the oxidiser pump to regulate the oxidiser-to-fuel mixture ratio.

anchors: What type of control system is deemed unsuitable for high-pressure staged-combustion cycles due to significant variations in pump discharge pressure?
positives: Engines which use orifices in the gas generator feed lines for thrust calibration or a turbine bypass for mixture ratio regulation are subject to large changes in thrust level, and therefore in pump discharge pressure, when their mixture ratio is varied. 302 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps This type of control system is unsuitable for high-pressure staged-combustion cycles, because of the high variations in the pump discharge pressure as a result of the series arrangement of the thrust chamber, the turbine, and the turbine hot-gas generator [12]..

anchors: What type of pump design is discussed quantitatively in the provided material?
positives: Centrifugal-flow pumps have been illustrated and described qualitatively in the preceding sections. Here, their design is described quantitatively.

anchors: What is the primary function of the rotating blades in a centrifugal pump's impeller?
positives: The impeller of a centrifugal pump is a bladed rotor shaped so as to sweep the pumped fluid roughly z/2 rad (or 90°) outward from the pump shaft. The fluid enters the pump in the axial direction and is swept radially by the rotating blades of the impeller. The following figure, due to the courtesy of Wikimedia [32], illustrates a rubber impeller shaped as a paddle-wheel, which has been used for the water pump of an outboard engine..

anchors: What parameters must be chosen by a designer to ensure maximum efficiency in the design of a centrifugal-flow pump's impeller?
positives: In the design of a centrifugal-flow pump, the values of some quantities, such as head rise AH (m), volume flow rate g (m/s), rotating speed w (rad/s), specific speed N, and suction specific speed S, are chosen by the designer. This done, the impeller for this pump is designed by choosing the velocities and the angles of its vanes in such a way as to obtain the desired properties with the maximum efficiency.

anchors: What coefficients and losses are important for designing an impeller in pump systems?
positives: For this purpose, it is possible to use design or experimental data on pump head coefficient vw, impeller vane coefficient ¢,, and impeller loss due to leakage q, (m/s). Finally, the impeller is designed according to the chosen values of the quantities mentioned above. 308 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps.

anchors: What is the typical range of the radial component of absolute flow velocity at the impeller entrance in meters per second?
positives: The values of some principal quantities are chosen as will be shown below.The radial component c,,; (m/s) of the absolute flow velocity at the impeller entrance depends on the inlet conditions, and in particular on the velocity of discharge at the outlet of the inducer, and on the diameter of the duct. Typical design values of Cm tange from 3.05 to 18.3 m/s [22].

anchors: What is the relationship between the radial flow velocity at the impeller exit and the impeller blade tip velocity along with the flow coefficient?
positives: The radial component c,,2 (m/s) of the absolute flow velocity at the impeller exit depends on the outlet conditions, and in particular on the tip velocity uz (m/s) of the impeller blades and on the flow coefficient g = C,,2/u2 at the impeller exit. Typical design values of c,,2 range from 0.01 wz to 0.15 uz [22].

anchors: What factors influence the diameter of an impeller at the entrance of its vanes?
positives: The diameter d, (m) of the impeller at the point of entrance of the vanes depends on the design of the inducer, on the diameter of the impeller shaft, and on the diameter of the impeller hub.

anchors: What is the equation used to calculate the tip velocity of impeller blades at exit using head rise and head coefficient?
positives: The tip velocity uw (m/s) of the impeller blades at the impeller exit can be computed by means of the equation y = go AH /u5, for given values of the head rise AH (m) and of the head coefficient y. The maximum design value of u2 depends on the strength of the material used. The latter, in turn, determines the maximum head rise which can be obtained with a single-stage impeller. Typical design values of uz range from 61 to 457 m/s [22].

anchors: How can the exit diameter be calculated using the known rotating speed and tip velocity?
positives: When the rotating speed w (rad/s) and the tip velocity u2 (m/s) have known values, then the impeller diameter d2 (m) at the point of exit can be computed as follows dz = 2u2/w..

In case of an impeller having backward- curved vanes, {> is to be determined by considering the curves expressing efficiency and head rise against volume flow rate. anchors: What are the benefits of using impellers featuring a reduced quantity of blades in terms of operational range stability and efficiency?
positives: From the point of view of manufacturing, impellers with a low number of blades are desirable. Impellers with blades curved backward (82 < m/2 rad) and low head coefficient w = go AH/u3 tend to have a wider and more stable operating range than impellers with radial blades (62 = 2/2 rad). However, the range of high efficiency for pumps with impellers of low head coefficient is smaller than the corresponding range for pumps with impellers of high head coefficient [3]..

anchors: What type of materials are commonly used to manufacture high-speed impellers for liquid hydrogen pumping?
positives: Impellers are fabricated by casting, machining, and diffusion bonding. Impellers having highest tip speeds (much above 300 m/s) are used for pumping liquid hydrogen. These impellers are of the open-face type, and are machined from high- strength forged materials, usually from the Ti-5AI-2.5Sn titanium alloy, extra-low- interstitial (ELI) grade. A figure illustrating one of such impellers for liquid-hydrogen pumps has been given in Sect.

anchors: What type of impellers are utilized for low-density propellants in rockets?
positives: 4.2. Shrouded impellers for dense fuels or oxidisers are cast, since the properties of cast materials are adequate for the required tip speeds of less than 300 m/s. Open-faced impellers for oxidiser pumps may be cast or machined. The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [5], illustrates unshrouded machined impellers for low-density propellants. These impellers have been used in the Titan II rocket..

They have also been fabricated by generating all the components separately from a titanium alloy, diffusion bonding them, and finishing internal passages by chemical milling [3].

anchors: What are the definitions of the abbreviations FLOX, IRFNA, and UDMH used in rocket propellants?
positives: Impeller materials which have been used successfully with liquid propellants for rockets are shown in the following table, due to the courtesy of NASA [3]. FLOX is a mixture of liquid fluorine (LF) with liquid hydrogen (LH2). IRFNA stands for Inhibited Red Fuming Nitric Acid (HNO3). UDMH stands for Unsymmetrical Di- Methyl Hydrazine (H2NN(CH3)2). Inconel 718 is a trade name of Special Metals for a precipitation-hardening nickel-chromium-iron alloy.

positives: “K” Monel indicates the MONEL® alloy K-500, which is a trade name of Special Metals for a precipitation- hardenable alloy containing nickel, copper, and aluminium..

anchors: What is the primary function of the axial inlet section of a pump rotor?
positives: The following section of the present section is meant to give criteria for designing an inducer, which is the axial inlet portion of a pump rotor and has the function of raising the inlet head of the pumped fluid by an amount sufficient to preclude cavitation in the following stages. An inducer may be an integral part of a pump rotor, 314 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps but may also be matched separately to the pump shaft upstream of the pump impeller.

anchors: What is the primary aim in the design of an inducer concerning suction performance and structural integrity?
positives: The principal objective in the design of an inducer is the attainment of high suction performance while maintaining structural integrity under all operating conditions [4]. An inducer is designed to operate at low inlet pressure under conditions of incipient cavitation, which fact permits a low pressure in the propellant tank. The inducer provides a sufficient head rise to avoid cavitation in the following stages of the pump [34].

anchors: What is the formula for determining the head rise due to an inducer in a pump system?
positives: The head rise due to the inducer ranges from 5 to 20% of the head rise of the pump. The required head rise AH;,z (m) due to the inducer at the design point for a given pump is expressed by the following equation ABing = (NPSHR) imp — (NPSHR) ina where (NPSH g)imp (m) is the required net positive suction head due to the impeller, and (NPSH pr) ina (m) is the required net positive suction head due to the inducer.

anchors: What is the relationship between the meridian velocity and the tangential velocity in determining an inducer's flow coefficient?
positives: The principal increase in static pressure in an inducer occurs at the leading edge of its vanes, because the velocity of the flow decreases there with respect to the vanes, and also because the angle of attack between the inlet flow and the vanes is small. The capability of an inducer to avoid cavitation depends on its flow coefficient gp = Cmo/Uo, Where C9 (m/s) is the meridian velocity of the fluid at the inducer inlet, and uo (m/s) is the tangential velocity of the blade at the inlet tip.

anchors: What must the angles between the vanes and a plane perpendicular to the rotation axis be for a pump with a high specific speed to achieve high suction specific speed?
positives: The value of the flow coefficient gp must be low for a pump of high specific speed N, in order for the pump to have a high value of suction specific speed S. To this end, the values of the angles 6, and 6), between the vanes and a plane perpendicular to the axis of rotation must 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 315 be small, as shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22], which illustrates an inducer of low head rise, having three vanes and a non-tapered hub.

anchors: What factors influence the selection of materials used for inducers in engineering applications?
positives: The materials of which inducers are made are usually chosen from alloys of stain- less steel (for example, 304 or 347), titanium (for example, Ti-SAI-2.5Sn ELI or Ti-6Al-4 V), and aluminium (for example, 7075-T73). The respective densities of these materials are approximately 8000, 4480, and 2810 kg/m?, and their strengths vary about in the same order as their densities. The choice of a specific material from those indicated above depends on their strength-to-weight ratio, chemical reactivity, cavitation erosion, and the need for special properties, such as ductility, notch tough- ness, etc.

anchors: Which type of alloy is noted for its lower machining costs compared to titanium alloys and is well-suited for low-stress applications?
positives: [4]. A cast aluminium alloy is the proper choice for an inducer subject to low stress when low cost is important. This is because aluminium is easy to forge and machine, but not apt to be welded or brazed. Titanium alloy parts are more expensive to machine than comparable parts of aluminium alloys, but less expensive than alloys such as Inconel® 718 or René® 41. Titanium alloys can be welded by gas-tungsten are or electron-beam processes. Proper welding procedures are to be observed for titanium alloys [4]..

anchors: How does introducing pre-whirl at the inlet enhance the performance of a pump during throttling conditions?
positives: An increase in the suction performance of a pump may be obtained by pre-whirl of the inlet flow. For this purpose, the inlet flow is mixed with high-velocity fluid taken from the pump discharge. This flow is injected through a ring of orifices in an axial direction upstream of the inducer. Pre-whirl introduced in this manner has improved flow distribution and reduced flow instabilities which may occur when a pump is throttled [4]..

anchors: What device can be added to the inlet line to mitigate the effects of reverse flow at low operational rates?
positives: Backflow occurs in an inducer at low flow (about 90% or less of the design value) as a result of local head breakdown in the tip region of the vanes. In order to reduce backflow or control its effects, a backflow deflector can be incorporated in the inlet line, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [4]. 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 321 || E Backflow

anchors: What is the relationship between the inducer inlet and the main adapter flow?
positives: LF = eee \ j Inducer Inlet Main | adapter flow i 1

anchors: What effects does a deflector have on head, NPSH, and low-frequency oscillations when operating below the design flow range?
positives: Below nominal flow, (between 20 and 90% of the design flow) where back- flow becomes important, the deflector results in increased head, reduced critical NPSH, and lower amplitudes of low-frequency oscillations. Above nominal flow, the deflector has a detrimental effect [4]. Further information on backflow control can be found in [35].

positives: e the casing, which is the part of the pump containing the impeller; e the diffusing system and the volute for single-stage pumps; and e the crossover system for multi-stage pumps.

positives: An example of a multi-stage centrifugal-flow pump is the Centaur (RL-10) liquid- hydrogen pump, which has two stages mounted with the impellers back-to-back with volute housing and an external diffusing passage between the two stages, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [3]. 334 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps External diffusing ~~ passage rd = ax \ Volutes t x AG {J N N qf Oe 4s DSSS Impellers 7 Y Ny N “ P ' ‘ 4 External diffusing passage.

anchors: What are the two types of diffusers mentioned that can be used in a diffusing system?
positives: The diffusing system may include vaned or vaneless diffusers upstream of the volute and one or more conical diffusers downstream of the volute. anchors: What components within a housing are responsible for supporting rotation and preventing fluid leakage?
positives: The housing also contains the bearings, which support the rotating element, and the seals, which prevent leakage of the pumped fluid.

anchors: What components within a pump are responsible for converting kinetic energy into pressure energy?
positives: The diffusing system and the volute form the part of the pump in which the kinetic energy impressed to the fluid by the rotating element is converted into pressure energy. The head loss due to friction at the inlet of a pump is very small, due to the short path and to the low velocity of the flow. The conical or cylindrical shape of the suction duct depends on whether the tip contour is or is not tapered.

anchors: What are the minimum inducer clearance-to-blade length ratios for fuel and oxidiser pumps, respectively?
positives: The best results have been obtained by tapering the contour of both the tip and the hub [22]. This is because the gradual reduction of the suction area upstream of the impeller eye makes the flow steady. 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 335 The rotating parts of oxidiser pumps must not be allowed to rub metal to metal. This rubbing may cause dangerous explosions in liquid-oxygen pumps. Practically attained minimum values of the inducer clearance-to-blade length ratio are 5% for fuel and 20% for oxidiser pumps.

anchors: What is the thickness of the polymer layer placed between the inducer blades and the suction duct wall for oxidiser pumps?
positives: When closer clearances are required for oxidiser pumps, a liner made of PCTFE (Poly-Chloro-Tri-Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Kel-F® or Neoflon®) should be used for the inducer casing. The chemical formula of this polymer is (CF,CCIF),, where n is the number of monomer units in its molecule. A layer of this material, 2.54 mm in thickness, is inserted between the tips of the inducer blades and the wall of the suction duct, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [4].

anchors: What is the nominal radial clearance for the inducer in a coated inlet?
positives: Wy nin ek NZ ) LOX inlet The RAN ANS VA Coated inlet Present inlet radial clearance tadial clearance Inducer 0.005 nominal 0.107 nominal.

anchors: What is the primary function of a conical nozzle in a system without static vanes?
positives: As has been shown here and also in Sect. 4.5, the diffusing system may, or may not, have static vanes. In case of a vaneless diffuser, the pumped fluid at the outlet of the impeller is discharged into a single volute channel, whose cross section increases gradually, and the conversion from velocity head to pressure head takes place principally in the conical nozzle at the outlet of the pump.

anchors: What is the primary advantage of a vaned diffuser compared to a vaneless diffuser in fluid pumping systems?
positives: In case of a vaned diffuser, the pumped fluid at the outlet of the impeller is discharged into a diffuser provided with vanes, and the same conversion takes place prevalently in the channels between the diffusing vanes, before the fluid has reached the volute channel. A vaneless diffuser has the advantage of simplicity, but a vaned diffuser is more efficient than the other.

anchors: What are the essential design parameters for a centrifugal-flow pump without a vaneless diffuser?

anchors: What is the significance of the angle that the flow at the impeller exit must match to prevent turbulence and downstream wear?
positives: These parameters are the area A, (m7) of the volute at the throat, the flow area Ag (m7), the angle 0, (rad) between the side walls of the volute, the volute tongue angle a, (rad), the radius 7, (m) at which the volute tongue starts, and the width b3 (m) of the volute. By volute tongue angle aw, we mean the camber angle formed by the tongue with the circumferential direction [25]. The direction of the flow at the exit of the impeller must match the angle @,,, in order to avoid turbulence and wear downstream of the tongue.

anchors: What should be the relationship between the volute tongue angle and the angle between the absolute and peripheral velocity vectors at the impeller outlet?
positives: For this purpose, the value of the volute tongue angle a, is chosen close to the value of the angle a’ between the absolute velocity vector c’> and the peripheral velocity vector u2 at the outlet of the impeller, that is, a, ~ a’. The values of the other parameters are discussed below, in accordance with the indications given in [22]..

anchors: What are the two methods employed to calculate the cross-sectional area of a volute at a specified angular distance from its tongue?
positives: The methods used to determine the cross-sectional area Ag of the volute at an angular distance 6 (rad) from the volute tongue are: (a) constant moment of momentum per unit mass; and (b) constant mean velocity.

anchors: What is the relationship between the circumferential component of velocity and the radius in a frictionless environment?
positives: In the method (a), the circumferential component c’,3 of the absolute velocity of the pumped fluid in the volute is assumed to be inversely proportional to the radius r (c'.3 r = constant), which would be true only in the absence of friction losses. After the shape of the volute has been determined, the volute cross-sectional area satisfying the given flow requirement is determined at each circumferential station.

anchors: What design approach was applied to create the pump housing for Titan I, Titan II, and the J-2S Mark 29 fuel pump?
positives: This method was used for the design of the pump housing of Titan I and Titan II. It was also used, corrected for friction losses, for the design of the J-2S Mark 29 fuel pump (illustrated in Sect. 4.7), which experienced very light radial bearing loads [3]..

In other terms, the constant mean absolute velocity c’3 is made equal to 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 337 gat bs “A, 2m Ao where q (m?/s) is the volume flow rate of the pump, A, (m7) is the area of the volute at the throat (where 6 = 0), and Ay (m7) is the area of the volute at an angular distance 6 (rad) from the volute tongue. This method was conceived to simplify the volute design..

anchors: What is the range for the radius at which the volute tongue should start, in relation to the outer radius of the impeller, to prevent turbulence?
positives: The radius r, at which the volute tongue starts should be from 1.05 to 1.1 times the outer radius rz of the impeller, in order to avoid turbulence.

anchors: What is the relationship between the width at the bottom of the volute and the impeller width for low specific speed pumps?
positives: The width b3 of the volute at the bottom of its trapezoidal cross section is chosen to be 2.0 times b2 (where bp is the impeller width at the outlet) in case of pumps of low specific speeds, and from 1.6 to 1.75 times b2 in case of pumps of high specific speeds.

anchors: What is the maximum angle measurement, in radians, recommended for the side walls of the volute?
positives: The maximum value of the angle 6, between the side walls of the volute should be about z/3 radians. A value smaller than this should be chosen for pumps of high specific speeds or high flow angles a’ at the impeller outlet.

anchors: What type of housing is utilized to minimize radial forces on the impeller shaft in centrifugal-flow pumps?
positives: The pressure exerted by the pumped fluid on the walls of the volute cannot be kept uniform under all operating conditions. Consequently, the impeller shaft is subject to a radial force. In order to eliminate or reduce this force, double-volute housings are used. A typical double-volute, single-outlet housing of a centrifugal-flow pump is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22]. 338 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps DIRECTION OF FLOW | : 7 ROTATION.

anchors: How does placing a second tongue at an angular distance impact the symmetry and resultant radial force in fluid dynamics?
positives: In the double-volute housing illustrated above, the flow forms two streams as a result of a second tongue placed at an angular distance of z radians from the first. This symmetry in the flow may reduce the total resultant radial force.

anchors: What is the purpose of the multiple passages in a diffuser equipped with fixed blades?
positives: A diffuser provided with static vanes has been illustrated in Sect. 4.5. The shape of the volute of a vaned diffuser is the same as that of a vaneless diffuser, but a vaned diffuser has a plurality of passages through which the pumped fluid flows from the impeller to the discharge nozzle. This fact makes it possible to convert the velocity head possessed by the fluid into pressure head in a narrower space than is the case with a vaneless diffuser.

anchors: What is the range for the radial distance from the impeller to the inlet tips of the static vanes?
positives: High performance is obtained by a small radial distance (from 0.8 to 3.0 mm, depending on the impeller diameter) between the impeller and the inlet tips of the static vanes. The width of a vaned diffuser at the inlet may be chosen to be from 1.6 to 2.0 times b) (where b is the impeller width at the outlet). With reference to the following figure, re-drawn from [22], the vane angle @3 at the inlet should be chosen equal or close to the angle a’, between the vectors c’2 and uz at the outlet of the impeller. 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 339 DIFFUSER VANES DIFFUSER THROAT DIFFUSER iN — VOLUTE —ee PASSAGE | aS | | Y Mix a, es |.

anchors: What types of materials are commonly utilized in the construction of diffuser vanes and housing structures?
positives: Materials used for this purpose are cast aluminium alloys, cast stainless steels, and high-strength wrought aluminium alloys and steels. Diffuser vanes can be integral or separate. External loads on the volute can be reduced by using flexible ducts [3]..

positives: The residual value of the axial force, after the application of a thrust balance system, must be so low as to be safely absorbed by the pump bearings [36]..

anchors: How do radial ribs influence the static pressure in the space adjacent to the impeller's back shroud?
positives: The radial ribs reduce the static pressure in the space between the back shroud of the impeller and the wall of the casing, because the pumped fluid spins in this space with the impeller. This rotational motion decreases the pressure exerted by the fluid with the radial distance from the impeller tips [12]. Holes may be provided through the impeller into the inside diameter region of the radial ribs to vent that region statically and to provide a positive coolant flow into the radial ribs to prevent cavitation caused by fluid heating which results from the pumping work of the radial ribs [3]. 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 345.

anchors: What design features were incorporated in the oxidiser pump impeller of the F-1 engine to manage axial force?
positives: The gear-driven pumps of the Titan launch vehicles had open-face impellers with radial ribs in the impeller hub, in order to reduce the axial force to a value which could be sustained by a split-inner-race ball bearing. The turbo-pump of the F-1 engine had shrouded impellers. In order to control the axial force, the impeller of the oxidiser pump of the F-1 engine had an inlet wear ring and radial ribs, whereas the impeller of the fuel pump of the same engine had inlet and hub wear rings.

anchors: What type of bearings support unbalanced axial force in a direct-drive turbine system?
positives: The pump forces balanced the direct-drive turbine forces, so that tandem split-inner-race ball bearings could sustain the unbalanced axial force [3]. 346 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps.

What mechanism is employed in a centrifugal-flow pump to balance axial thrust between components, specifically mentioned in the design of the Mark 48-O turbo-pump?
positives: Still another method to control axial thrust in a centrifugal-flow pump uses a self-compensating balance piston. This method was used in the Mark 48-O (liquid oxygen) turbo-pump, which was designed to achieve a balance of axial thrust between the pump and the turbine. For this purpose, the back side of the pump impeller contains a balance piston, which is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [37].

anchors: What is the function of the high-pressure orifice in the context of the balance piston operation?
positives: The rotating member of the balance piston is the rear shroud of the impeller. To operate the piston, high-pressure liquid oxygen from the impeller discharge passes through a high-pressure orifice located at the outer diameter of the impeller into the balance piston cavity. From this cavity, the liquid oxygen passes through a low-pressure orifice near the impeller hub into the balance piston sump. From there, the liquid oxygen returns to the eye of the impeller through axial passages in the diffuser vanes and radial holes in the diffuser and inlet [38].

anchors: Explain the function of a diffuser in a centrifugal-flow pump. How does it contribute to the pump's performance?
positives: 4.9 Design of Centrifugal-Flow Pumps 347 DIFFUSER HIGH-PRESSU%E ORIFICE fj “1 , <N —\! \) y ‘ \ S 6 WS BALANCE PISTON CAVITY MSS | \ LOW-PRESSURE ORIFICE X Lp ‘. \ GS BALANCE PISTON ‘SUMP \\.

anchors: What effect occurs due to the variance of high-pressure and low-pressure orifice openings with the rotor's axial position?
positives: The thrust-compensating effect is obtained because the openings of the high- pressure orifice and of the low-pressure orifice vary with the axial position of the rotor. Therefore, the axial force due to the pressure on the rear shroud of the impeller varies correspondingly. For example, an unbalanced load toward the pump inlet causes a reduction in the high-pressure orifice gap and an increase in the low-pressure orifice gap. This, in turn, causes a reduction in the pressure force of the impeller rear shroud, introducing a compensating load change [38]..

anchors: What properties must be considered when selecting materials for systems that manage thrust in relation to safety, strength, and compatibility with propellant?
positives: Materials used for thrust balance systems are chosen taking account of their compatibility with the propellant, strength at the required rotating speed, and safety in the event of an inadvertent rub. Plastic materials such as PCTFE (Poly-Chloro- Tri-Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Kel-F® or Neoflon®), PTFE (Poly-Tetra- Fluoro-Ethylene, whose trade name is Teflon®), and fluorinated PVC (Poly-Vinyl- Chloride) resist burning if rubbed on the impeller in liquid-oxygen pumps, and there- fore are safe stationary sealing materials when the difference of the seal pressure is not excessive.

anchors: What materials are recommended for components in liquid-hydrogen pump systems to prevent galling during contact?
positives: These materials are also satisfactory for liquid-hydrogen pumps. 348 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps Materials for balance-piston orifices are chosen to resist galling if rubbed against.

anchors: What properties must materials for orifices in balance pistons used in liquid-oxygen pumps possess to ensure safety and stability?
positives: balance-piston rotor or impeller materials. In case of balance pistons used in liquid- oxygen pumps, materials used for orifices must resist explosion or ignition upon impact, and must also be physically and chemically stable in liquid oxygen. The following table, due to the courtesy of NASA [3], indicates materials used for thrust balance systems.

anchors: What pressure increase in pascals is generated by a single-stage centrifugal-flow pump when pumping liquid hydrogen with a head rise of approximately 19,800 meters?
positives: “Material Suitable for use with LOX 4.10 Design of Axial-Flow Pumps Apart from the case of inducers, axial-flow pumps have been used in rocket engines only when the pumped propellant is liquid hydrogen, because this fluid requires high values of volume flow rate and head rise. For this purpose, such pumps have been used in the multi-stage configuration only. The head rise AH made available by a typical single-stage centrifugal-flow pump, when the pumped fluid is liquid hydrogen, is about 19,800 m, which corresponds to a pressure rise Ap of about 70.85 x 9.807 x 19,800 = 1.376 x 107 N/m?.

anchors: What is the head rise range achievable per stage with a multi-stage axial-flow pump?
positives: This is due to the very low density p = 70.85 kg/m? of liquid hydrogen. When higher values then these are required for AH and Ap, then a multi-stage axial-flow pump is chosen. A pump of the latter type makes it possible to obtain a head rise ranging from about 1520 to 2740 m for each stage [22]..

anchors: What is the minimum volume flow rate necessary for axial-flow pumps used with liquid hydrogen?
positives: The volume flow rate q of axial-flow pumps used for liquid hydrogen cannot be lower than about 0.347 m?/s, because the height of the rotor or stator vanes of such pumps cannot be lower than about 12.7 mm, for manufacturing reasons. For values greater than 0.347 m/s of volume flow rate and in the range from 9140 to 19,800 m of head rise, the design requirements of a liquid-hydrogen pump can be satisfied by either a single-stage centrifugal flow pump or a multi-stage axial flow pump.

anchors: What maximum flow rate in cubic meters per second is associated with the use of a centrifugal-flow pump for liquid hydrogen?
positives: In practice, a centrifugal-flow pump for liquid hydrogen is chosen when the volume flow rate required is lower than 0.0158 m/s [22]..

anchors: What assumption is made regarding the meridian component of the absolute velocity vector in an axial-flow pump?
positives: The meridian or axial component c,, of the absolute velocity vector ¢ of the flow is assumed to have a constant value in all the stages (rotor and stator) of an axial-flow pump. This assumption requires a constant area of the cross section of the pump, in order for the equation of continuity of flow to be satisfied. By so doing, the effects of frictional drag at the walls of the housing and at the vanes are neglected..

anchors: What change occurs in the tangential component of the absolute velocity vector of fluid as it passes through the stator of an axial-flow pump?
positives: The stator of an axial-flow pump converts much of the head of the pumped fluid due to the tangential component c’,,3 of its absolute velocity vector c’3 at the outlet of the rotor vanes into pressure head. For this purpose, the curvature of the stator vanes is such as to reduce the tangential component of the absolute velocity vector of the flow. By contrast, the axial component c’,,3 of the vector c’3 does not change, because the passages between stator and rotor perpendicular to the axial direction have the same cross-sectional area.

anchors: What happens to the chord-to-pitch ratio as the diameter of the stator vanes increases from the hub to the tip?
positives: The diameters d, (m) and d;, (m) of the stator at respectively the tip and the hub can be considered equal to the diameters of the rotor at respectively the tip and the hub. The value of the chord-to-pitch ratio C,/P, of the stator vanes increases as their diameter increases from d;, to d,. The length L, (m) of the stator vanes in the axial direction is usually chosen equal to the length L, (m) of the rotor vanes in the same direction..

anchors: What is the relationship between the angles chosen for the inlet of the stator vanes and the absolute velocity vector at that location?
positives: The velocity diagrams at the inlet and at the outlet of the stator vanes are drawn assuming the absolute flow velocities and the angles to be equal to the absolute velocities and to the angles at the inlet and at the outlet of the rotor vanes. The vane angles a3 at the inlet of the stator vanes are chosen slightly greater than the angles a’; formed there by the absolute velocity vector c’; with the tangential direction (a3 = a’; + i), in order for the fluid to be deflected effectively.

anchors: What is the range for the ratio of impeller hub diameter to impeller tip diameter in liquid-hydrogen axial-flow pumps?
positives: Typical design values for these quantities are given below for liquid-hydrogen axial-flow pumps, according to [22]. The ratio ry = d;,/d, of the impeller hub diameter dj, to the impeller tip diameter d, ranges from 0.76 to 0.86. The specific speed for each stage (NV), ranges from 1.1 to 1.8. The head coefficient for each stage (Ww); = g0(AH),/u2, ranges from 0.25 to 0.35. The solidity of the rotor vanes S, = C,/P, at the mean effective diameter ranges from 1.0 to 1.3.

anchors: What is the relationship between the solidity of stator vanes and the mean effective diameter in terms of its specific range?
positives: The solidity of the stator vanes S, = C,/P, at the mean effective diameter ranges from 1.5 to 1.8. The number of vanes of the rotor Z, ranges from 14 to 20. The number of vanes of the stator Z, ranges from 35 to 45. The value of Z, should have no common factor with the value of Z,, in order to avoid resonance phenomena. The head rise produced by the moving vanes of an impeller rotor depends on the value of the angular difference B; — f, called vane curvature..

anchors: What parameters are essential for determining the number of stages in a multi-stage axial-flow pump?
positives: The design method used for a multi-stage axial-flow pump is similar to the method described in Sect. 4.9, which relates to a single-stage centrifugal pump. The difference between the two methods consists in the determination of the number of stages of the axial-flow pump. The latter method is described below. The system requirements relating to the rocket engines give the values of some basic quantities, such as the total head rise AH (m) of the pump, the volume flow rate g (m/s), and the required net positive suction head (NPSH) x (m).

anchors: What design approach is used for the Mark 9 and Mark 25 pump rotors involving clamping of components?
positives: A one-piece rotor structure, machined from a single forging, has been used for the Mark 15-F (see part (A) of the preceding figure) and Mark 26 pump rotors. Axial holes have been machined in the forging to provide a return flow path for thrust balance system and bearing coolant flows. The Mark 9 (see part (B) of the preceding figure) and Mark 25 pump rotors have been fabricated according to the build-up concept with the disks and stub shafts clamped together through bolts.

anchors: What method is employed to achieve relative radial positioning in the mentioned structure?
positives: Rabbets have been used to attain relative radial positioning, the torque loads being transmitted by shear in the tie bolts. The M-1 rotor (see part (C) of the preceding figure) is a hollow structure fabricated from four forged and machined ring components TIG-welded together [2]..

anchors: What are the key structural characteristics of the hub in an inducer for an axial-flow pump?
positives: the method described in Sect. 4.9, which relates to an inducer for a centrifugal-flow pump. The inducer used for an axial-flow pump has often a cylindrical casing, vanes of a constant tip diameter, and a highly tapered hub. In other words, the hub diameter increases from a small value at the inlet of the inducer to a greater value at the outlet of the inducer, at which point the hub diameter is close to the impeller diameter.

anchors: What is the primary function of the stationary component located downstream of the rotating inducer in terms of energy conversion?
positives: A stationary part of the inducer (inducer stator) is placed downstream of the rotating part. The inducer stator is aimed at converting much of the velocity head, imparted to the pumped fluid by the rotating part of the inducer, into pressure head. The inducer stator is also aimed at discharging the fluid so that its absolute velocity vector c’> should have a magnitude c’, and a direction a’, as close as possible to respectively the magnitude c’, and the direction a’, of the absolute velocity vector c’, of the fluid at the outlet of the impeller stator..

The value of Z;; should have no common factor with the value of the impeller rotor vanes Z,, in order to avoid resonance phenomena.

anchors: What is the primary function of the vanes in the exit passage of an axial-flow pump?
positives: The volute portion of an axial-flow pump is designed so that the flow from the last axial stage is ducted to an exit passage, and is gradually turned toward a plane normal to the rotation axis of the pump, before being collected in the volute proper. Vanes are used in the exit passage to guide and diffuse the flow, and also to tie the volute walls together structurally. The volute portion of the Mark 15-F pump and its diffuser vanes are shown in the following figure, adapted from [2]. 4.10 Design of Axial-Flow Pumps 361 PUMP VOLUTE T+<7* RZ | Z oa LaNe* SS DIFFUSER Ni an (2 sy THRUST-.

anchors: How does a folded volute influence the overall weight and performance stability of a diffuser?
positives: A folded volute permits a smaller overall housing envelope, which results in a lower weight. In addition, a folded volute can be used to obtain a single-vortex rather than double-vortex motion in the volute. This kind of motion is particularly effective to increase efficiency in a volute-exit conical diffuser and to stabilise performance [2].

anchors: What is the typical range of diffuser vanes in a turbo-pump?
positives: The number of diffuser vanes ranges usually from 17 to 23 [22]. This number should have no common factor with the number of impeller rotor vanes, in order to avoid resonance phenomena. The vane angle a,, shown in the following figure, adapted from [2], can be determined by drawing the velocity diagrams for the diffuser vanes. The line, which forms the angle a, with the chord line, is normal to the plane of the row of diffuser vanes. 362 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps a LINE MEAN CAMBER se an LINE Sng FA “sy Z fa > ea *.

anchors: What is the typical range of flow velocity in the volute of axial-flow pumps for liquid hydrogen?
positives: Incase of axial-flow pumps for liquid hydrogen, the design velocity of flow in the volute ranges from 30.5 to 45.7 m/s [22]. The cross section of the volute has usually a circular shape, due to the high pressure. The boil-off of liquid hydrogen is limited as far as possible by using high-quality thermal insulating materials applied to the external surface of the pump.

anchors: What components are utilized in an axial-flow turbo-pump to manage significant axial thrust loads resulting from pressure and fluid momentum variations?
positives: In an axial-flow turbo-pump, thrust bearings and compensating balance pistons are used to counteract the high axial thrust loads due to pressure forces and fluid momentum changes in the pump and in the turbine [2].

anchors: What components are involved in the balance scheme of a specified turbo-pump design as depicted in a certain figure?
positives: The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [36], shows the balance piston and bearing scheme chosen for the Mark 15-F turbo-pump. 4.10 Design of Axial-Flow Pumps 363 Balance piston BY (AZZ? = Lp ies ry ie a) Gb Y iy p ZZ Spring preloaded ball bearings

anchors: What component of the rotor assembly contains variable openings and has seals positioned on both its front and rear sides?
positives: The balance piston, which is part of the rotor assembly, is a disk having variable orifices with a pair of seal rubs located one on the front side (left in the figure) and the other on the rear side (right in the figure) of the disk. High-pressure fluid coming from the pump discharge is introduced into the thrust balance system and flows through the two variable orifices in series with a low-pressure area..

anchors: What effect does a reduction of pressure in the control chamber have on the motion of the rotor assembly within the pump?
positives: When an axial thrust moves the rotor assembly toward the inducer of the pump, then the balance piston closes the high-pressure orifice at the front seal rub and opens the low-pressure orifice at the rear seal rub, thereby reducing the pressure in the control chamber placed between the two seal rubs. This reduction of pressure counteracts the hydraulic axial thrust acting on the rotor assembly toward the inducer, and restrains the motion of the rotor assembly in that direction.

anchors: What effect does an increase in pressure in the control chamber have on the rotor assembly's position regarding the reverse axial thrust?
positives: Likewise, when a reverse axial thrust moves the rotor assembly towards the discharge of the pump, then the balance piston opens the high-pressure orifice at the front seal rub and closes the low-pressure orifice at the rear seal rub, thereby increasing the pressure in the control chamber placed between the two seal rubs. This increase in pressure counteracts the reverse axial thrust acting on the rotor assembly toward the discharge, and causes the rotor assembly to return to its neutral position.

anchors: What are the advantages of impulse turbines over reaction turbines in the context of rocket engine pumps?
positives: Elements of the impeller stator vanes: v3 = 0.6349 rad, a4 = 777/18 = 1.222 rad, a. = 0.9285 rad, S; = 1.61, Z; = 41, Ps = 0.01265 m, C, = 0.02037 m, L, = 0.01631 m, and R, = 0.03520 m. 4.11 Design of Turbines 379 4.11 Design of Turbines Pumps for rocket engines are usually driven by impulse turbines, whose working principle has been described in Sect. 4.3. This is because impulse turbines are simpler and lighter than reaction turbines.

anchors: How does the required power influence the number of stages in a turbine design for a rocket engine?
positives: The design of a turbine for a rocket engine is based on the following considerations. The number of stages depends on the power required.

anchors: What does the design isentropic velocity ratio indicate regarding turbine efficiency?
positives: As has been shown in Sect. 4.3, the design isentropic velocity ratio determines the range of efficiency of a turbine. The isentropic velocity ratio for a single-stage turbine is U/Co, where U (m/s) is the peripheral velocity of the blades, Co = (2 Ahr)? (m/s) is the isentropic spouting velocity, and Ahr (J/kg) is the enthalpy drop per unit mass of the working fluid through a turbine. For a N-stage turbine, the isentropic velocity ratio is (U7 + U3 + --- + U2)*/Co.

anchors: What relationship is illustrated in the graph regarding the efficiency of turbines with different impulse and reaction staging configurations?
positives: A plot of isentropic velocity ratio versus turbine efficiency 77 is given in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [15], which illustrates the variation in peak efficiency for 1-, 2-, and 3-row impulse staging turbines and for reaction staging turbines. 380 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps oe 100.

anchors: What values represent the isentropic velocity ratio from the minimum to maximum range specified?
What range of efficiency is observed for two-row turbines utilized in specific engine cycles according to the design isentropic velocity ratios?
positives: These curves make it possible to establish and compare initial estimates of effi- ciency for turbines of new design. In practice, design isentropic velocity ratios for two-row turbines used in gas-generator and tap-off engine cycles (see Sect. 4.4) range from 0.1 to 0.4, and corresponding efficiencies vary from 35 to 65% [15]. Staged- combustion and expander-cycle turbines reach efficiencies above 80%, because the lower values of the turbine system pressure ratio po/p. permit operation in a range of velocity ratios corresponding to higher efficiency, as has been shown quantitatively in Sect. 4.8..

anchors: What is the range of peripheral velocities for the turbine blades in the rocket engine turbines?
positives: Peripheral velocities U of current turbine blades vary from 305 to 457 m/s, and associated inlet temperatures for liquid oxygen/RP-1 and for liquid oxygen/liquid hydrogen turbines range from 811 to 1089 K. Rocket engine turbines have been operated successfully without cooling at inlet temperatures of 1200 K [15].

anchors: What factors influence the number of stages in a turbine of a new design?
positives: The number of stages in a turbine of new design depends on the quantity of energy possessed by the unit mass of the working fluid and made available to the turbine. It also depends on a compromise between a gain in turbine efficiency and the added mass due to the further turbine stages required to increase performance. In a study of staging, pressure ratios and enthalpies per unit mass are varied in several possible configurations, to determine the design point corresponding to the highest efficiency with the smallest pitch diameter and the least number of stages.

anchors: What are the typical configurations of turbines used for rocket engines, and what is the main reason for this preference?
positives: Current turbines are usually of the single-row or two-row axial type. This is due principally to size and mass restrictions affecting turbines used for rocket engines. Impulse-type staging is usually specified in turbines of new design with isentropic velocity ratios below 0.35. These turbines operate with high-energy working fluids and at pressure ratios which raise the stage spouting velocity into the supersonic domain.

anchors: What type of turbine is typically selected for a direct-drive configuration with pumps on a single shaft?
positives: Reaction turbines are used with low pressure ratios (<2) and isentropic velocity ratios above 0.45 [15]. 4.11 Design of Turbines 381 In a direct-drive arrangement, when the pumps and the turbine are mounted on a single shaft, the rotating speed w (rad/s) of the turbine and therefore the isentropic velocity ratio U/Co have values lower than the ideal ones. In this arrangement, a single-stage, two-row, velocity-compounded impulse turbine is generally chosen, as is the case with the Mark 10 turbo-pump illustrated in the following figure, adapted from [5].

anchors: What is the input rotational speed of the Mark 3 turbo-pump in radians per second?
positives: By contrast, in a geared, offset-turbine arrangement, the presence of a gearbox makes it possible to operate the turbine at rotational speeds much higher than those which are possible with a direct-drive arrangement. For example, for the Mark 3 turbo-pump described at length in Sect. 4.5, the input rotational speed is 3434.8 rad/s, and the speed reduction ratio input/pump-shaft is 4.885 for both of the pumps [15]. Consequently, the Mark 3 turbo-pump has a two-stage, pressure-compounded impulse turbine..

anchors: What properties of the working fluid are essential for determining the rotor size of an impulse turbine?
positives: After the type of impulse turbine and the number of its stages have been deter- mined, it is necessary to determine the size of its rotor. To this end, it is necessary to know the properties (inlet temperature To, specific heat ratio y, etc.) of the working fluid, the pressure ratio po/p- of the turbine, and the rotation speed w of the pumps. 382 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps

anchors: What factors influence the selection of rotor tip diameter in relation to efficiency, size, mass, and operational stresses?
positives: The rotor tip diameter d, (m) is chosen by taking account that a large diameter results in a high isentropic velocity ratio U/Co and a high efficiency 7, but also in high size, high mass, and high stresses in operating conditions. Therefore, the rotor tip diameter results from a compromise.

anchors: What factors must be considered when calculating the total power needed for a turbine, including losses and auxiliary requirements?
positives: The useful power Py (W) delivered by the turbine shaft must be equal to the sum of the net power required by the pumps, the power loss in the gearbox (if any), and the power required by auxiliary drives. After the power resulting from this sum has been determined, the required mass flow rate my (kg/s) of the working fluid can be determined by using the following equation of Sect. 4.8:

anchors: How does a nozzle transform the energy of a working fluid in terms of temperature and pressure when it moves through the system?
positives: The nozzles convert the potential energy of the working fluid into kinetic energy by reducing the temperature and the pressure of the fluid as it passes through the vane channels. The kinetic energy is then converted to work as the working fluid passes through the rotor blades [15]. The path followed by the working fluid through a two- row impulse turbine as that of the Mark 10 turbo-pump is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22]. 384 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps FLOW.

anchors: What factors contribute to the non-isentropic expansion of a gas in a nozzle and lead to increased temperature during the flow?
positives: The expansion of a gas flowing through an actual nozzle is not isentropic, due to the viscosity of the working fluid, friction, boundary-layer effects, etc. The loss of kinetic energy due to friction and turbulence in the flow causes an increase in temperature (reheat) in the gas flowing through a nozzle. Therefore, the actual velocity C, of the gas at the exit of a nozzle is lower than its spouting velocity Co, which is calculated assuming an isentropic expansion.

anchors: What factors contribute to the effective area of a nozzle being smaller than its geometric area?
positives: In addition, the effective area of a nozzle is less than its geometric area, due to boundary-layer effects and circulatory flow. These phenomena can be taken into account by means of the coefficients defined below..

anchors: What is the mathematical relationship between the actual velocity and the spouting velocity of gas in a nozzle, represented by a specific coefficient?
positives: The nozzle velocity coefficient k,, is defined as the ratio of the actual velocity C; (m/s) of the gas at the exit of a nozzle to its spouting velocity Co (m/s), as followsk= 2 Co where Co is calculated assuming an isentropic expansion of the gas from the total pressure at the inlet of the nozzle to the static pressure at the inlet of the rotor blade, as will be shown below.

anchors: What are the potential ranges for the nozzle velocity coefficient in turbine design?
positives: The values of the coefficients k,,, 1, and €,,, defined above depend on the geometric and thermodynamic properties of a turbine. Design values of these coefficients, deter- mined experimentally or by experience acquired from existing rocket turbines, are given below. Design values of the nozzle velocity coefficient k, range from 0.89 to 0.98. Consequently, design values of the nozzle efficiency n, = k? vary from 0.79 to 0.96. Design values of the nozzle throat area coefficient ¢,, vary from 0.95 to 0.99 [22]..

anchors: What geometric shapes can the cross section of rocket turbine nozzles take based on the relationship between width and height at the throat?
positives: The cross section of the nozzles in a rocket turbine may be either a square or a rectangle, according to whether the width b,, (m) normal to the flow direction at the throat of a nozzle is equal to or different from the radial height h,, (m) at the same point, as shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [22].

anchors: What angle represents the change in direction of gas flow in the nozzle from the inlet to the outlet?
positives: The nozzles are closely spaced on either a circular arc which extends over a part of the circumference or the whole circumference. With reference to the following figure, the direction of the gas expanding through a nozzle is approximately axial at the inlet of the nozzle, and changes so as to form an angle a (rad) with the plane of rotation at the outlet of the nozzle. Therefore, the gas flow turns in the nozzle through an angle of 2/2 — a.

anchors: What is the typical range for the angle formed by the central line of the nozzle with the rotation plane at its outlet?
positives: Let 6,, (rad) be the angle which the central line of the nozzle forms with the plane of rotation at the outlet of the nozzle. The choice of the value of 0, is left to the designer. Usually, this value ranges from z/12 to 7/6 radians [22]. The angle a is generally greater than 6, due to the unsymmetrical shape of the nozzle at the outlet..

anchors: What elements are commonly included in Stellite® 21 besides cobalt and chromium to enhance its properties?
positives: Stellite® 21 is a cobalt-chromium alloy, which is designed to be resistant to wear, corrosion, and heat. The alloys of the Stellite group may also have some portions of tungsten or molybdenum and some small but critical amounts of carbon. Stellite is a trademarked name of Deloro Stellite Company supplying Stellite alloys like Stellite 3, Stellite 6, Stellite 12 and Stellite 21.

anchors: What type of super-alloys is known for superior resistance to oxidation and thermal fatigue?
positives: Inconel® (comprising 713C, 718, X-750, ...) is a family of austenitic nickel- chromium based super-alloys having excellent resistance to oxidation and thermal fatigue, as has been shown in Chap. 2, Sect. 2.5.

anchors: What are the primary ingredients found in the corrosion-resistant alloys known for their high thermal and mechanical stress resistance?
positives: Hastelloy® is a registered trademark name of Haynes International, Inc., which is applied as the prefix name of a range of corrosion-resistant metal alloys under the term super-alloys or high-performance alloys. The principal ingredient of these alloys is nickel. Other ingredients are molybdenum, chromium, cobalt, iron, copper, 4.11 Design of Turbines 389 manganese, titanium, zirconium, aluminium, carbon, and tungsten in various percent- ages. The primary quality of the Hastelloy alloys is resistance to high thermal and mechanical stresses..

anchors: What is the difference in radius between the outermost and innermost sections of a blade called?
positives: The tip and the hub are respectively the outermost section and the innermost section of a blade.The radial height /, (m) of a blade is the difference between its radius at the tip and its radius at the hub.The blade pitch P, (m) or blade spacing, measured at the mean diameter d,,,, is the distance in the direction of rotation between corresponding points of two adjacent blades.

anchors: What is the term used to describe the concave surface of a blade where maximum pressure occurs?
positives: The pressure surface is the concave surface of a blade, where the pressure reaches its maximum value.

anchors: What defines the line connecting the front and rear points of a blade section when placed on a flat surface?
positives: The suction surface is the convex surface of a blade, where the pressure reaches its minimum value.The leading edge and the trailing edge are respectively the front (or nose) and the rear (or tail) of a blade.The chord line is the line between the two points in which the front and the rear of a blade section touch a flat surface, on which the blade section is placed with its convex surface upside.

anchors: Define the term used for the perpendicular projection length of a blade profile onto the line connecting the leading and trailing edges.
positives: The chord C, (m) is the length of the perpendicular projection of the blade profile onto the chord line. This length is approximately equal to the distance between the leading edge and the trailing edge.

anchors: Define the projection length of a blade onto a line aligned with the turbine axis. What is the significance of the mean line in a blade profile?
positives: The axial chord is the length of the projection of a blade, as set in the turbine, onto a line parallel to the turbine axis.The camber line is the mean line of a blade profile, and extends from the leading edge to the trailing edge, halfway between the pressure surface and the suction surface.

anchors: What geometric relation is defined by the intersection of the tangents to a specific line at both the front and back edges?
positives: The camber angle is the external angle formed by the intersection of the tangents to the camber line at the leading edge and at the trailing edge.

anchors: What is the relationship between a turbine blade's height and its axial length known as, and what is its design value range?
positives: The stagger angle is the angle between the chord line and the axial direction of the turbine.The blade aspect ratio is the ratio of the height h, to the axial length C;, of a blade. Design values of the aspect ratio range from 1.3 to 2.5 [22].The solidity of a blade is the ratio of its chord C; to the pitch P, of the blade. Design values of a blade solidity range from 1.4 to 2.0 [22].

anchors: What factors determine the adequacy of rotor blade numbers to effectively direct fluid flow in a system?
positives: The nozzle pitch P,, and the blade pitch P,, can be chosen independently from each other, as long as the number Z, of the rotor blades is sufficient to direct the flow. This number depends on the aspect ratio and on the solidity of the blades, and should not have any common factor with the number of the nozzles or with the number of the stator blades.

anchors: What types of geometric shapes can be combined to form a blade profile?
positives: A blade profile has segments of straight lines combined with circular arcs or parabolic arcs or both. anchors: What is the term for the radius of the circular arc on the pressure surface of a blade, known as rr?
positives: The pressure surface of the blade is concave, and the radius of its circular arc is designated with rr. The suction side of the blade is convex, and the radius of its circular arc is designated with r,. The two tangents at the two endpoints of the circular arc on the pressure side form two angles (0,; and 6). at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the blade) with the direction of rotation. The thickness of the blade at its leading edge and at its trailing edge is designated with t,..

anchors: What condition occurs if the angle at the rotor blade inlet is less than the angle formed by the relative velocity vector at that point?
positives: As shown in the preceding figure, the angle 0, should be sightly greater than the angle 6, formed by the relative velocity vector V; with the direction of rotation at the inlet of the rotor blades. If it were otherwise (0,; < £1), the flowing gas would impinge on the blades just at the inlet, with consequent losses. The angle 6,2 is usually chosen equal to the angle 62 formed by the relative velocity vector V2 with the direction of rotation at the outlet of the rotor blades. 396 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps.

anchors: What type of seals are utilized in a two-stage turbine to minimize leakage between the blades and stages?
positives: For example, in the model A3-3 pressure-compounded, two-stage turbine used in the RL 10 engine, the blades are fully shrouded, and labyrinth seals are incorporated to reduce blade and interstage leakage. In this turbine, shown in Sect. 4.13, the aluminium shrouds are brazed to the blade tips and to the vane roots.

anchors: What design feature in turbine rotors contributes to efficiency improvements in impulse turbines compared to rotors lacking this feature?
positives: Experimental test data have shown that turbine rotors with shrouded blades, when compared to rotors with unshrouded blades, are capable of providing effi- ciency advantages in impulse turbines. This increased performance is attributed to the reduced amount of blade-tip unloading and leakage of the shrouded blades. Turbines developing powers equal to or greater than 373 kW, including the turbines for the J-2, F-1, and M-1 engines, have shrouded blades [15].

anchors: What feature of an interconnected blade system provides damping and opposes rotational motion?
positives: The shroud forms frequently an integral part of the blade, and the shroud of each blade fits closely to the shroud of the contiguous blade, as shown in the following figure, adapted from [15], which illustrates an interlocking rubbing shroud, providing damping and resistance to blade torsional motion. 398 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps 4 % > /t i P my” 6 p 4 ra 2.54 cm A.

anchors: How can the roots of blades be secured to a rotating structure, and what joint types are utilized for this connection?
positives: The shroud may also form a continuous ring, in which case it is either attached or welded to the blade tips. The roots of the blades may be either welded to the disc or attached to it by using dove-tail or fir-tree joints, as has been shown in Sect. 4.3.

anchors: What effect does tapering a blade have on the tensile stress experienced at its root section?
positives: The loads acting on the rotor blades of a turbine are due to the following causes. The first cause is the centrifugal force acting on each blade. This force produces a tensile stress which reaches its maximum value at the root section of a blade. In order to reduce this stress, a blade can be tapered by making its section at the tip narrower than its section at the root. In addition, the centres of mass of the sections of a blade at various radii do not belong to a radial line.

anchors: What generates maximum bending moments at the root section of a blade due to the offset centers of mass?
positives: Therefore, the centrifugal forces acting in these offset centres of mass of a blade generate bending moments, whose value is also maximum at the root section of the blade..

anchors: What influences the bending moment on a turbine blade during gas flow, particularly concerning the force components generated by momentum change?
positives: The second cause is the bending moment due to the gas flow through the blades. The momentum change of the gas flow generates a force, which has a radial compo- nent, which drives the turbine, and an axial component. This force, in turn, generates a bending moment acting on the blade. For the purpose of determining this bending moment, the force due to the momentum change of the flowing gas can be considered as acting at the mid-height of the blade..

anchors: What should the frequency of a vibration force be in relation to natural frequencies to prevent significant bending stresses?
positives: The third cause is the bending moment due to a vibration force. This is because the gas flow through the blades is not uniform, but varies periodically between a maximum and a minimum value. The frequency of this force should not be equal to any of the natural frequencies of the blade, in order to avoid bending stresses of considerable magnitude. A careful design of the blades can offset part of the bending moment due to the gas flow by using the bending moment due to the centrifugal force.

anchors: How can the bending stresses at the root be determined using the resultant bending moment?
positives: The bending stresses at the root can be computed from the resultant bending moment.

anchors: How is the total stress at the root of a rotor blade determined when a separation shroud is included?
positives: The vibration stresses can be estimated from data on blades designed previously. When a rotor blade is fitted with a separation shroud, the centrifugal force due to the shroud produces additional stress at the root. In this case, the total stress due to centrifugal forces results from summing the stress due to the blade to the stress due to the shroud.

anchors: What are the three main factors contributing to the stresses experienced by a turbine disc?
positives: The stresses acting on the disc of a turbine are due to the following causes. The first cause is the stress due to the rotor blades. The second cause is the stress due to the centrifugal forces acting on the material of which the disc is made. The third cause is the stress due to the torque acting on the disc. 400 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps The discs of turbines are usually thick near the axis and thin near the rim where the blades are attached.

anchors: What factors influence the estimation of tensile stress in a turbine disc, excluding blade effects?

anchors: What is the purpose of the stationary blades in a two-row, velocity-compounded impulse turbine?
positives: The following discussion deals specifically with the design of a single-stage, two- row, velocity-compounded impulse turbine. We assume the expansion of gas to take place only in the nozzle, without further expansion in the rotor blades. Since the gas possesses a considerable amount of kinetic energy at the outlet of the first row of rotating blades, then a row of stationary blades (stator) is necessary to direct the flow to the inlet of a second row of rotating blades, which extract a further amount of kinetic energy from the gas.

anchors: What is the directional characteristic of gas flow at the exit of the second row of blades in the turbine?
positives: At the outlet of the second row of rotating blades, the gas flows at low velocity in a direction close to the axial direction of the turbine. The vectors V; and V> are the relative velocities of the gas flow at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the first row of rotating blades. The vector Cy is the absolute velocity of the gas flow at the inlet of the stator. The vector C) forms an angle a2 with the plane of rotation.

positives: The vector C3 is the absolute velocity of the gas flow at the inlet of the second row of rotating blades. The vector C3 forms an angle a3 with the plane of rotation. The vectors V3 and V, are the relative velocities of the gas flow at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the second row of rotating blades. The velocity of the flow at the outlet of any row of blades, be they rotating or stationary, is lower in magnitude than the velocity of the flow at the inlet, because of losses due to friction.

anchors: What is the characteristic change observed in the height of symmetrical blades from one row to the next in a two-row velocity-compounded impulse turbine?
positives: The design of a single stage, two-row velocity-compounded impulse turbine is similar to that of a single-stage, single-rotor impulse turbine, which has been described above. The difference is in the fact that the velocity vectors change in magnitude and in direction for each row of blades. Therefore, the height h, of symmetrical blades in the radial direction is constant in each row, but increases from one row to the next in the direction of the exhaust..
