anchors: What are the angles formed by the absolute velocity vectors with the plane of rotation in a pressure-compounded impulse turbine?
positives: Each stage of a pressure-compounded impulse turbine can be considered sepa- rately from the other stages. The vectors C, and C; are the absolute velocity vectors, whose magnitudes C; and C3 are the spouting velocities of the gas at the outlet of respectively the first-stage nozzle and the second-stage nozzle. The vectors C; and C3 form the angles respectively a; and a3 with the plane of rotation. The magnitudes C, and C3 of C; and C3 are chosen to be about the same..

anchors: What are the angles formed by the relative velocity vectors at the inlet and outlet of each rotor with the rotational plane?
positives: The vectors V; and V> are the relative velocity vectors of the gas at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the first-stage rotor. The vectors V; and V2 form the angles respectively 6; and £2 with the plane of rotation. Likewise, the vectors V3 and V4 are the relative velocity vectors of the gas at respectively the inlet and the outlet of the second-stage rotor. The vectors V3 and V4 form the angles respectively 63 and £4 with the plane of rotation..

anchors: What is the relationship between the pressure changes and the velocity increase during the gas flow expansion in the nozzle of the second stage?
positives: The nozzle of the second stage is designed in such a manner as to receive the gas flow coming from the rotor of the first stage in the direction of the absolute velocity vector C>, and to change the direction of this flow from a to a3. At the same time, the gas flow not only changes its direction, but also expands at a lower pressure and increases the magnitude of its absolute velocity from Cz to C3.

anchors: What is the direction of the absolute velocity vector when the gas exits the rotor of the second stage?
positives: Now, the gas flow enters the rotor of the second stage in the direction of the absolute velocity vector C3, and exits from this rotor in the direction of the absolute velocity vector C4. The vector U is the peripheral velocity of the rotors at the mean diameter..

anchors: What is the relationship between the velocity diagrams of the first and second stages when power is extracted equally in both stages?
positives: The total power extracted from the gas expanding through the turbine results from the sum of the power extracted in the first stage and the power extracted in the second stage. A turbine can be designed in such a way as to extract power in equal parts in the two stages. In this case, the velocity diagram of the first stage is equal to the velocity diagram of the second stage, so that the vectors C; and C3 are equal in 4.11 Design of Turbines 405 direction and in magnitude, and the vectors Cz and C4 are also equal in direction and in magnitude..

anchors: What is the range of values for the carry-over ratio in a pressure-compounded impulse turbine?
positives: Part of the heat generated in the first stage of a pressure-compounded impulse turbine due to friction con be converted into useful work in the second stage. In addition, part of the kinetic energy possessed by the gas flow at the outlet of the first stage of this turbine can be used in the second stage for the same purpose. This part of kinetic energy is measured by the carry-over ratio r,, whose value ranges from 0.4 to a number close to unity.

anchors: What is the ratio of useful work derived from kinetic energy in the second stage to the total kinetic energy in the first stage?
positives: The carry-over ratio is the part of kinetic energy possessed by the gas flow leaving the first stage which is converted into useful work in the second stage to the total kinetic energy possessed by the gas flow leaving the first stage..

anchors: What turbine design consists of two stages and two rotors, specifically for a rocket engine, focusing on power extraction from expanding gas?
positives: The following example of application concerns the design of a two-stage, two- rotor, pressure-compounded impulse turbine for a rocket engine. The data are for this turbine are the same as those for the velocity-compounded turbine described in the preceding example. As has been shown above, a pressure-compounded turbine can be designed in such a way as to extract power from the expanding gas in equal parts in the two stages.

anchors: What method is utilized to find the partial enthalpy reductions per unit mass in a nozzle and rotor for matching power extraction in stages?
positives: To this end, it is necessary to execute a procedure of trial and error to determine the partial isentropic drops of enthalpy per unit mass in the nozzle and in the rotor of each stage which result in about the same amount of power extracted in each stage. In the present example, the stage carry-over ratio is assumed to be re =0.91..

anchors: How does the mean diameter of a pressure-compounded turbine compare to that of a velocity-compounded turbine?
positives: The two examples considered above show that a pressure-compounded turbine has a higher total efficiency than that of a velocity-compounded turbine of the same prop- erties. However, the greater mean diameter of the former (1.083 m against 0.7424 m) implies greater size and mass.

anchors: What types of bearings are utilized in turbo-pumps to ensure efficient load handling and speed management?
positives: The shaft of a turbo-pump is supported by two or more bearings. They are placed as closely as possible to major rotating components, in order to reduce radial movements and to control critical speeds. Ball bearings and cylindrical roller bearings are used because of their capabilities in terms of load, speed, stiffness, and misalignment tolerances. Tapered roller bearings, needle bearings, and pure-thrust ball bearings 4.12 Bearings for Turbo-Pumps 431 have not been used in rocket engine turbo-pumps, due to their limited speed capa- bilities [36].

anchors: What is the primary function of bearings in a rotating shaft assembly within a turbo-pump?
positives: As has been shown in Sect. 4.2, the bearings are used to absorb the radial and axial loads transmitted through the shaft, to keep the rotating parts of the turbo-pump in position and in correct alignment with the fixed parts, and to permit the shaft to rotate with the least possible amount of friction. The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [12] shows the bearings (two forward bearings and one aft bearing) which support the shaft of the Mark 10 turbo-pump.

anchors: What is the function of the rotors in relation to the flow of working fluid in a turbine system?

anchors: What types of forces act on the shaft of a turbo-pump, and how are they oriented in relation to the shaft axis?
positives: Some of the forces acting on the shaft of a turbo-pump are directed radially, that is, perpendicularly to the shaft axis; others are directed along the shaft axis.

anchors: What factors contribute to radial forces in rotating machinery components?
positives: The radial forces are due to the weights of components (such as shafts, impellers of pumps, rotors of turbines, and gears), to centrifugal forces acting on rotating parts, to forces of inertia caused by accelerations, to non-uniform distribution of pressure in the discharge volute of pumps, and to tangential forces caused by the presence of rotating gears.

anchors: What factors contribute to the axial forces acting on a vertical shaft in rotating machinery?
positives: The axial forces are due to weights of rotating parts mounted on a vertical shaft, to unbalanced axial thrust caused by the pumps, and to axial thrust acting on the blades of turbine rotors.

anchors: What advantages do ball bearings and cylindrical roller bearings offer for turbo-pumps in rocket engines compared to fluid film bearings?
positives: As has been shown above, ball bearings and cylindrical roller bearings are gener- ally used for turbo-pumps of liquid-propellant rocket engines. This is because they have the following advantages over fluid-film bearings:

anchors: What are the characteristics that support autonomous operation without relying on external systems or materials?
positives: e ability to operate independently of external pressurising systems; e ability to operate satisfactorily after ingesting foreign material;¢ tolerance for short periods of coolant or lubricant absence;e high rate of radial spring; and 432 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps © low generation of heat and low consumption of coolant or lubricant.

anchors: What materials compose the races and rolling elements in the described hybrid ball bearing?
positives: A hybrid ball bearing, with races made of 60NiTi alloy and balls made of Si3N4, is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [43]. By race we mean the track or channel in which the rolling elements ride.

anchors: What are the main components of a ball bearing and how do they differ from those in a cylindrical roller bearing?
positives: Ss caorzaet TA. Notional Aeroneutics and Space Acmnstraton ‘John Ht Glenn Research Genter at Lewis ietdA ball bearing comprises an inner ring, an outer ring, and a plurality of balls placed between the two rings and held in their proper positions by a cage or separator. By contrast, in a cylindrical roller bearing, the rolling elements are cylinders of slightly greater length than diameter.

anchors: What factors influence the load capacity of Conrad-type ball bearings?
positives: Conrad-type ball bearings (so named after their inventor, Robert Conrad) are often used, because they can support a combined radial and axial load, a thrust load in both directions along the shaft axis, and moment loading. Their capacity depends on the number of balls used for them. This number is limited by the assembly method. They require a two-piece cage, which limits their speed capability [36]..

anchors: What type of bearing is utilized when thrust loads exceed the capacity of a single unit?
positives: Split-inner-ring ball bearings and angular-contact bearings, which have 30% more capability to support thrust than Conrad-type bearings, are used singly or in tandem to support heavy axial loads. Tandem duplexed ball bearings are used when the thrust load is greater than the capability of a single bearing. Two or three bearings are used to share the loading [36]. 4.12 Bearings for Turbo-Pumps 433 Cylindrical roller bearings have several times the capacity to support radial loads and the stiffness of ball bearings.

anchors: What parameter combines the inner diameter of a bearing in millimeters and the shaft speed in RPM to measure bearing speed?
positives: They are used to support only radial loads. Axial loads are supported by ball bearings axially connected to the roller bearing shaft. The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [36], shows how a thrust-carrying ball bearing (right) is used to eliminate axial loads from a roller bearing (left). Integra! mounting flange . Roller Grind relief WY, beari . > NS Roller Zale <A RX SSrass \N WY bearing aK WSs Ns SPSAV SSS NS py// HepPSS SSG ee WAS, Thrust carrying [Bol Zh pRO SPP Nassisy gear Snap ring , Gearbox ‘Quill shatt A parameter often used to measure a bearing speed is DN, which is the product of the bearing bore (the inner diameter of the inner ring) expressed in mm and the shaft speed expressed in rpm.

anchors: What are the maximum DN values achieved for different bearing types in operational turbo-pumps with specified coolants?
positives: Table III in [36] indicates the approximate maximum values of DN which have been achieved for bearings in operational turbo-pumps with specified coolants. These values range from 1.6 x 10° (for Conrad-type ball bearings and cylindrical roller bearings) to 2.06 x 10° (for angular-contact ball bearings). The value of DN is proportional to the tangential velocity of the bearing at the inside diameter of the inner race.

anchors: What factors contribute to bearing failure when the maximum permissible limit of a specific value is surpassed?
positives: When the maximum allowable limit of DV is exceeded, then lubrication and cooling are insufficient, and the bearing may fail due to overheating, contact wear, and fatigue. Since the value of DN is proportional to the shaft diameter, it depends on the bearing location. The following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [12], shows the most common locations for bearings. 434 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps \ ; j 00 \ ug.

anchors: What type of bearings are referenced with the term "outboard"?
positives: {c) Outboard bearings (d) Outboard bearings without

anchors: What is the benefit of mounting the pump and turbine on the same shaft in rocket engine turbo-pumps?
positives: The arrangement (a) of the preceding figure has frequently been used for rocket engine turbo-pumps in which the pump and the turbine are mounted on the same shaft. The J-2, RL10, and F-1 engines are examples of this arrangement, which has the advantage of avoiding the additional supporting structure and the separate lubrication and sealing systems which are required for the arrangements (b), (c), and (d)..

anchors: What is the significance of sizing the shaft below critical speed when considering turbo-pump operation over varying speeds?
positives: For the arrangement (a), the shaft is often sized so that the turbo-pump speed is below the lowest value of the critical speed, which is that due to the simple shaft bending. This sizing is particularly important if the turbo-pump must operate over a wide range of operating speeds (throttling). Sobin et al. [12] indicate the following equation to estimate this limiting speed of the shaft:

anchors: What is the value of the coefficient KpnP when utilizing two pumps on the shaft with dense propellant?
positives: 1.053 (DN)? o = —-—— KpnP? where w (rad/s) is the rotational speed of the shaft, P (W) is the power on the shaft, and K py is a coefficient whose value, determined empirically, is 325 for one pump 4.12 Bearings for Turbo-Pumps 435 on the shaft and low-density propellant (liquid hydrogen), 374 for one pump on the shaft and dense propellant, and 478 for two pumps on the shaft and dense propellant.

anchors: How can the positioning of the pump bearing between two specific components affect the maximum permissible speed?
positives: Some increase in the speed limit can be obtained by placing the pump bearing between the inducer and the pump impeller, according to the arrangement (e) of the preceding figure, and using the inducer stator to support it.

anchors: What is the relationship between torsional stress and the diameter of a shaft in the context of turbo-pump design?
positives: By placing the turbine bearing overboard, according to the arrangement (b) of the preceding figure, the shaft diameter can be sized by torsional stress. This results generally in a smaller shaft diameter, and therefore the turbo-pump can be designed for a higher speed. Sobin et al. [12] indicate the following equation to express the speed w (rad/s) as a function of the torsional stress which would occur in a solid shaft equal in diameter to the shaft diameter at the bearing:.

anchors: What is the correlation value of equivalent-shaft stress in N/m² as found by Sobin et al.?
positives: 1 op = 4388 x 10-6r3,(DN)? P2 where Teg (N/m?) is the torsional stress of a solid shaft of the same outside diameter at the bearing. Sobin et al. [12] have found a good correlation with the final design by using a value of 1.724 x 10° N/m? for the equivalent-shaft stress.

anchors: What effect does relocating the bearing on the pump end between the inducer and impeller have on the required diameter and torque?
positives: Even higher speeds may be obtained by moving the bearing on the pump end to a location between the inducer and the impeller, according to the arrangement (c) of the preceding figure. This placement reduces the required bearing diameter by reducing the torque transmitted through the bearing bore.

anchors: What arrangement permits the placement of a pump bearing outboard when a boost pump supplies adequate net positive suction head?
positives: With a boost pump, a main pump inducer may not be needed, because the boost pump would provide sufficient net positive suction head for the main pump impeller. In this case, the pump bearing can be placed outboard, according to the arrangement (d) of the preceding figure.

anchors: What are the necessary properties for propellants used in turbo-pump bearings to ensure effective cooling and lubrication?
positives: The coolant and the lubricant used for the bearings of turbo-pump are often the propellants themselves. This practice has the advantage of eliminating a separate system of cooling and lubrication. A small quantity of the pumped propellant is bled from a region of high pressure of the pump, flows through the bearings, and re-enter into a region of low pressure of the pump. For this purpose, the propellants must be thermally stable at the operating temperature, chemically inert with the materials of which the bearings are made, and sufficiently viscous..

anchors: What is the arbitrary factor by which the calculated Bjo fatigue life of bearings exceeds the turbo-pump life?
positives: The design data concerning the capacity to carry loads, the operating speed, and the life in service possessed by bearings are usually specified by their manufacturers. Table II in [36] contains a summary of capabilities possessed by bearings used for turbo-pumps of liquid-propellant rocket engines. The required life in service for a turbo-pump ranges usually from | to 2 h [36]. Bearings are designed for this life service by specifying a calculated Bjo fatigue life, including speed effects, which exceeds the turbo-pump life by an arbitrary arbitrary factor, whose value is usually set to 10.

anchors: What is the purpose of selecting a specific value in engineering design beyond preventing fatigue failures?
positives: This value is chosen not only to prevent fatigue failures, but also to compen- sate for other unquantifiable life-reducing factors, such as the low lubricity of most propellants and coolants. The Bjo fatigue life is the operating time which 90% of identical bearings can exceed without fatigue failure. It is calculated by relating the 436 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps stress cycles of a new design to the statistically analysed results of repeated fatigue tests on controlled test bearings [36]..

anchors: What type of seals are specifically utilized in turbo-pumps to mitigate the leakage of propellants between moving and stationary components?
positives: The seals considered in this section are devices used in turbo-pumps of rocket enginesto prevent or reduce the leakage of propellants or other fluids between the rotatingparts (shaft, pump impeller, and turbine blades) and the stationary parts (stators and casing) of a turbo-pump. Therefore, only rotating seals are considered here.

anchors: How can seals be categorized according to the guideline introduced by Zuk?
positives: Following the criterion proposed by Zuk [44], these seals can be classified into the

anchors: What are the subcategories of the first category that involve selection and management of the sealing area?
positives: The first category include the seals which depend on the selection and control of the sealing region. This category includes the following subcategories: © positive rubbing contact seals, which in turn include mechanical face seals,circumferential shaft riding seals, lip seals, and soft packing seals;

anchors: What types of seals are designed to function with clearances between 0.025 and 0.25 centimeters?
positives: e seals which operate at close clearances (ranging from 0.025 to 0.25 cm), which in turn include hydrodynamic seals, hydrostatic seals, and floating bushing seals; and

anchors: What are the two main categories of seals based on their operational principles concerning the gap between a rotating shaft and a stationary component?
positives: e fixed clearance seals (where the seal is in the gap between the rotating shaft and the stationary sleeve), which in turn include fixed bushing seals and labyrinth seals.The second category includes the seals which depend on the control of properties of the fluid. This category includes the following subcategories: © controlled heating and cooling seals; and e ferromagnetic seals.

anchors: What subcategory of seals relies on the management of forces affecting the fluid?
positives: The third category includes the seals which depend on the control of forces acting on the fluid. This category includes the following subcategories: © centrifugal seals;

anchors: What types of seals are commonly utilized in the turbo-pumps of rocket engines as per the provided data?
positives: This section describes briefly only those of the seals indicated above which have most frequently been used in turbo-pumps of rocket engines, according to the data given in Table 1 of [45]. The seals used in valves will be described in Chap. 5, Sect. 5.8.

anchors: What are the two classifications of mechanical seals utilized in turbo-pump applications?
positives: Two types of mechanical face seal are shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [44]. 4.13. Seals for Turbo-Pumps. 437 SECONDARY SEAL 7 LOW PRES- 1 SURE, Po ia <=" seine. He | Ae “ INTERFACE _r Housinc or SEAL RING —) 3 | 3 = _ ¢ =—= See PTT

anchors: What component prevents the rotation of the sealing ring in relation to the rotating seal seat?
positives: On the left-hand side, a rotating seal seat is mounted to the shaft and is held in close vicinity of a non-rotating sealing ring. The sealing ring is held in close vicinity of the seat by a mechanical spring. The sealing ring is allowed to move axially to follow the axial motion of the seal seat, such as run-out. Anti-rotation lugs, not shown in the preceding figure, prevent sealing ring rotation.

anchors: What is the purpose of the secondary seal in relation to the axial motions experienced by the sealing ring?
positives: Relative motion of the sealing ring and the stationary housing occurs across a secondary seal, which is shown as an O-ring in the preceding figure. The secondary seal may also be a piston ring, in case of high temperatures. The secondary seal fulfils the function of allowing the sealing ring to track axial motions of the seal seat. Since it is practically impossible to locate the seal seat to be perfectly perpendicular to the axis of rotation, then axial run-out occurs.

anchors: What design feature allows the sealing ring to adjust to the misalignment caused by axial movement in sealing applications?
positives: In order to reduce the leakage due to this run-out, small axial movement of the sealing ring is allowed. In other words, the spring forces the sealing ring against the rotating seal seat to follow the run-out or wobble. The secondary seal and ring function may be combined into one integral unit, as shown on the right-hand side of the preceding figure, where a bellows is used. The seal shown on the left is internally pressurised.

anchors: What type of flow occurs with a viscous fluid when pressure decreases linearly at the primary sealing interface?
positives: For this purpose, the pressurising fluid is located on the inner diameter of the seal and is separated from the low-pressure environment located at the outside diameter. By so doing, the pressurising fluid cannot leak to the external environment. The same seal is also pressure-balanced. At the primary sealing interface, leakage occurs and the pressure of the fluid decreases. In case of a laminar flow of a viscous fluid, the pressure decrease is linear, as shown in the preceding figure.

anchors: What term describes the force that opposes the sealing ring and is counterbalanced by spring and hydrostatic forces?
positives: The force due to this pressure decrease is called the seal separating force. The spring force and a hydrostatic force, which act against the sealing ring, counterbalance the seal separating force and hold the sealing ring against the seal seat. 438 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps.

positives: Two types of circumferential shaft riding seal are shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [44].a yy 2 r COVER RING Yy, “Lt " Besos if ~ SEAL RING “) \SLe S\AUNG = AT

anchors: What is the function of a garter spring in a segmented seal ring design?
positives: The seal ring shown on the left-hand side of the preceding figure consists usually of three segments, in order to permit radial misalignment of the shaft and also the motion of the shaft, and still maintain a very small gap. A retainer cover prevents leakage of the segment joints, and a garter spring keeps the segmented seal rings in close vicinity of the seal shaft. The type of seal shown on the left-hand side of the preceding figure is completely unbalanced.

anchors: What factors contribute to the functionality of circumferential seals when subjected to significant axial movement?
positives: By contrast, the other type shown on the right-hand side of the same figure is partially pressure-balanced, because it has pressure-relief slots which result in only a small net unbalanced force in both the axial and the radial direction. Circumferential seals cannot be completely balanced. In addition, they are very sensitive to the installation. They are used when the shaft is subject to large axial movement, because they are more tolerant of pressure reversals than face seals..

anchors: What are the components of a sealing mechanism that prevent lubrication loss while managing low or zero pressure differences?
positives: A lip seal consists of the seal case, the stiffener ring, and the primary lip, which is held in close vicinity of the shaft by a garter spring. This type of seals is generally used for low or zero differences of pressure. For example, it is used to prevent an oil mist, which lubricates a bearing, from leaking to the external environment. Tip seals are cheap, compact, and easy to install. However, since they are made of elastomeric materials, the elastomer may be incompatible with the sealed fluid, and may also be subject to stress relaxation..

anchors: What are the functions of constrictions and cavities in labyrinth seals to control fluid leakage?
positives: Six types of labyrinth seal are shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [45]. They are fixed clearance devices which restrict fluid leakage by dissipating the kinetic energy of the flow through a series of constrictions and cavities, which accelerate or decelerate the fluid or change abruptly the direction of flow, to create the maximum friction and turbulence.

anchors: What is the primary purpose of a labyrinth in the context of throttling energy transformation within a turbo-pump system?

In practice, a labyrinth transfers a considerable amount of kinetic energy from one throttling to the next [45]. anchors: What is the reasoning for mounting fuel and oxidiser pumps on the same shaft in rocket engines with similar density propellants?
positives: Therefore, turbo-pumps of latest design have the pump connected directly to the turbine [12]. This is because, for rocket engines using propellants which do not differ much in density (for example, liquid oxygen and RP-1), the rotational speeds of the two pumps are about the same, and therefore the fuel pump and the oxidiser pump can be mounted on the same shaft, as in the F-1 engine. For rocket engines using propellants which differ widely in density (for example, liquid oxygen and 442 4 Feed Systems Using Turbo-Pumps liquid hydrogen), the two pumps are mounted on separate shafts, each of them being driven by its own turbine, so that each pump can operate at its optimum rotational speed, as in the J-2 engine..

anchors: What size limitations are generally associated with geared turbo-pumps regarding turbine speed and blade height?
positives: In general, geared turbo-pumps are restricted to those of small size, in which the turbine speed must be high enough to obtain reasonable blade heights, and in which multiple turbines would require excessive control elements in terms of size and mass [12].

anchors: What method allows for misalignment correction by rocking the ball bearing in gear systems?

This method tolerates misalignment by rocking the ball bearing, so that the teeth of the idler gear line up with the teeth of the driving gear. anchors: What defines a dynamical system in the context of behavior over time in response to external influences?
positives: The engine of a rocket vehicle is a particular case of a dynamical system. By system we mean a collection of parts or elements or components which work together to attain an object. By dynamical system we mean a system whose behaviour changes with time in response to an external stimulus or force. In case of an engine of a rocket vehicle, the object of the system is the generation of a thrust vector having the desired magnitude and direction..

anchors: What term describes the component of a system that is responsible for converting incoming signals into outgoing signals?
positives: A dynamical system has inputs (or signals coming in), outputs (or signals going out), and an internal processor which transforms inputs into outputs. The part of a dynamical system which transforms inputs into outputs, that is, the processor of signals, is also known as the plant. The plant is the part of a dynamical system which fulfils the function of receiving, handling, and emitting signals.

anchors: What do the lines and boxes in a graphical representation of a dynamical system signify?
positives: A dynamical system is usually represented graphically by means of a block diagram, in which lines indicate input or output signals, and boxes indicate the plant or other components of the system, as shown in the following figure.

anchors: What defines a rocket vehicle as a particular type of dynamical system in relation to its mission outcomes?
positives: In case of a rocket vehicle, the success or the failure of the mission of the vehicle depends on the outputs of the various components or subsystems of which the system is made. Therefore, a rocket vehicle belongs to a particular class of dynamical systems, which are called controlled systems.

anchors: What is the primary goal of manipulating a system within engineering disciplines?
positives: Controlled systems exist in several fields of engineering. Controlling a dynamical system means regulating, or commanding, or governing that system in order to reach © The Editor(s) (if applicable) and The Author(s), under exclusive license 447 to Springer Nature Switzerland AG 2021 A. de Iaco Veris, Fundamental Concepts of Liquid-Propellant Rocket Engines,

anchors: Define the arrangement of components that regulate a system to achieve a specific objective.
positives: Springer Aerospace Technology, https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-54704-2_5 448 5 Control Systems and Valves a desired goal. A control system is an arrangement of components connected one to another for the purpose of regulating the system itself or another system to be controlled by the first.

anchors: What type of system does not modify its behavior based on feedback from the output signals it produces?
positives: A control system which cannot adjust itself or another system to input signals received is called an open-loop system. An open-loop system is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [1], which illustrates two systems which are connected between them, because the output signals u of the first (controller) are also the input signals of the second, which is the controlled system. Therefore, the first system controls the second system, but is not controlled by it.

anchors: What type of control system does not allow the output signal to influence the input of the control process?
positives: There is no mutual control of one system over the other. In other words, a system whose output signal y has no effect upon the input to the control process is called an open-loop control system..

anchors: What type of control system adjusts itself in response to input signals?
positives: Acontrol system which can adjust itself or another system to input signals is called a closed-loop or feedback system. A closed-loop system is shown in the following figure, re-drawn from [1], which illustrates two systems which have mutual control one over the other.

anchors: What type of control system incorporates feedback from the output to influence the system's response?
positives: In other words, a closed-loop control system is a control system in which some function of the output y of some part of the system is fed back as a secondary input which adds to the primary input r to the system, so as to affect the response of the system itself. As an example of a control system for a rocket vehicle, Lorenzo and Musgrave [2] describe a pressure-fed bi-propellant engine, in which the propel- lants are kept under pressure in their respective tanks and then supplied to the main combustion chamber through appropriate feed lines, control valves, and injector elements, as has been shown in Chap. 3. The propellants are to be delivered to the main combustion chamber in a determined mixture ratio.

positives: fms where mz, and rity are the mass flow rates of respectively the oxidiser and the fuel, and at a total mass flow rate mm, = m, +m, related to the desired thrust. The control system of this rocket engine regulates the thrust by controlling the pressure p, of the gas in the combustion chamber and the mixture ratio o/f of the two propellants, as shown in the following figure, adapted from [2]. 5.1 Fundamental Concepts on Control Systems 449 -. anchors: What is the primary function of the fast control loop in a propellant system?
positives: The preceding scheme has two control loops. One of them controls the mixture ratio o/f of the propellants, and the other controls the pressure p, of the gas in the combustion chamber. The first loop operates usually, but not necessarily, on the propellant supplied at higher mass flow rate than the other. This loop is tuned to be the fast loop. This reduces excursions in the mixture ratio away from the set point, which in turn keeps the temperatures of the gas and of the metal at the design conditions.

anchors: What are the essential measurements and control inputs required for managing the combustion chamber's pressure in the slow loop?
positives: The second loop, which controls the pressure of the gas in the combustion chamber, is the slow loop, and its bandwidth is set by thrust response requirements. The type of control shown above requires three measurements (p¢, 7, and my) and two control inputs for the valve areas A, and A, [2]..

anchors: What are the limitations of an open-loop control system in managing variable conditions for a rocket engine's performance?
positives: An open-loop control system for a rocket engine is calibrated to a fixed set of conditions, and uses orifices and on-off command devices to correct deviations of some parameters from their design values. For example, orifices of proper size are inserted into the flow lines to command pressure drops, and the mass flow rates of the propellants are controlled by opening or closing valves. An open-loop control system is simple, but is also limited to a specific set of parameters, and cannot compensate for variable conditions.

anchors: What type of control system utilizes sensors and computers to identify and correct errors without needing calibration for specific conditions?
positives: The sequence times in an open-loop control system are often established by means of interlocks. 450 5 Control Systems and Valves A closed-loop control system uses sensors, computers to detect errors (which are differences between a given reference signal r and the output y of the system), and actuation commands u generated by the computers to correct the errors. Therefore, a closed-loop control system does not require calibration for a specific set of conditions.

anchors: What type of system employs sensors and computers to identify discrepancies and implement corrective actions in rocket engines?
positives: It requires sensors and computers to detect errors and take appropriate steps to correct them. A closed-loop control system is often used in a rocket engine to control the mixture ratio o/f of the propellants, and the thrust vector F in magnitude and direction. A closed-loop control system in a rocket engine may operate in one of the modes indicated below. (1) On-off control, which can be described as follows: ua | timax ife>0 ~ | umin if e < 0 where the control error e = r — y is the difference between the reference signal r and the output y of the system, and uw is the actuation command.

anchors: What value of the actuation command is typically set when the control error is within a narrow range around zero?
positives: The preceding equation does not define a value of the actuation command u when the control error e is equal to zero. In practice, u is taken equal to zero (u = 0) when the control error e is in a narrow band centred around e = 0. The on-off control is used for a rocket engine, for example, when a pressure switch opens or closes a valve which regulates the pressure in a tank. (2) Proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control, which can be described as follows: Umax if @ > max u=ykpe if emin < @ < @max Umin if e < emin where k, is the controller gain, @min = Umin/kp, and @max = Umax/kp.

anchors: What term describes the range within which a controller behaves linearly when the error is within specified limits?
positives: The interval (€min, @max) is called the proportional band, because the behaviour of the controller is linear when the error e = r — y is in this interval, as follows u=k,(r—y)=kpe if emin < @ < €max In a proportional control, the process variable often deviates from a reference value. When some level of the control signal u is required for the system to maintain a desired value, then the control error e must be other than zero to generate the required value.

anchors: What control strategy uses the integral of error over time to achieve zero steady-state error?
positives: For this purpose, the control signal u is made proportional to the integral of the error over a given time interval, as follows t u(t) = k; | e(t)dt 0 5.1 Fundamental Concepts on Control Systems 451 where k; is the integral gain. This type of control is called integral control. A controller with integral control has zero steady-state error [1]..

anchors: What is the purpose of a PID controller in a system affected by oscillations?
positives: Unfortunately, there may not always be a steady state, because the system may be subject to oscillations. anchors: What three time-related terms contribute to the control signal in the given system, and how are they weighted?
positives: By so doing, the control signal u(t) results from the sum of three terms: the term relating to the present time is proportional, through the coefficient k,, to the error at the present time; the term relating to the past time is proportional, through the coefficient k;, to the error cumulated over an interval before the present time; and the term relating to the future time is proportional, through the coefficient ky, to the error resulting from a linear extrapolation of the error at some time ahead of the present time [1].

anchors: What are the components of a control system used for managing pressure, propellant mixture, and thrust direction in a rocket engine?
positives: The proportional-integral-derivative control is used for a rocket engine in several cases, for example, to control the pressure in the combustion chamber (proportional term), or the mixture ratio of the propellants (integral term), or the direction of the thrust vector with phase lead (derivative term). An example of a closed-loop control system for a rocket engine has been given by Huzel and Huang [3] by means of the following scheme, re-drawn from [3]..

anchors: What is the function of the valve in regulating the mass flow rate within a gas generator for a control system?
positives: This control system illustrated above has the purpose of maintaining the value p. of the pressure in the combustion chamber equal to a desired value p, of reference, by using a valve which controls the value m, of the mass flow rate in the gas generator (GG). The magnitude F of the thrust vector is controlled indirectly, by regulating the pressure p, in the combustion chamber. 452 5 Control Systems and Valves.

anchors: What are the components involved in a control system that regulates mass flow using a pressure sensor?
positives: This control system consists of a sensor (chamber pressure transducer), a computer containing an electric summing junction and an electric amplifier, and a controller (gas generator flow control valve) which regulates the value of the mass flow rate m in the gas generator. The computer compares the reference input signal r with the input signal y coming from the sensor (chamber pressure transducer).

anchors: How does the signal r correlate with the reference pressure and what is the relationship between the signal y and the actual pressure in the combustion chamber?
positives: The signal r is related to the reference pressure p,, and the signal y is related to the actual pressure Pc in the combustion chamber through differential equations, which describe the behaviour of the components of the system..

anchors: What symbols represent the relationships between input and output in control systems using components identified by letters?
positives: The letters A, B, C, and D in the preceding figure indicate the relations existing between the input and the output of the respective components. The equations which govern this control systems can be written symbolically as follows

anchors: What is the importance of properly selecting gains and response lags in a control system?
positives: The behaviour of this control system results from the solution of the preceding equations. These equations are usually solved by using the method of the Laplace transformation (see, for example, [4]). The values to be given to the gains and to the response lags of a control system are to be chosen carefully, sometimes by trial and error, in order not to introduce overshoots or other causes of instability, which could give rise to large oscillations..

anchors: What tasks do control systems in liquid-propellant rocket engines perform regarding engine operation, malfunctions, and propellant management?
positives: The control systems described in general terms in the preceding section are used inliquid-propellant rocket engines to perform some or all of the following tasks:© engine restart, in case of engines having restart capability;e change of the given plan of operation, or even engine shutdown, in the presence of a malfunction;¢ propellant tank filling up; 5.2 Control Systems for Rocket Engines 453

anchors: What method is used to chill components such as pipes and valves in cryogenic propellant systems?
positives: e incase of cryogenic propellants, chilling pipes, pumps, cooling jackets, injectors, and valves by bleeding the cold propellants through them;

anchors: What processes must be performed to ensure key parts function correctly before a flight and to prepare engines for subsequent uses?
positives: e check-out the proper operation of critical components before flight; ande incase of recoverable and reusable engines, recycling and refurbishing the engines to put them in conditions of readiness for a new use.

anchors: What types of devices are primarily utilized for control functions in liquid-propellant rocket engines?
positives: In the specific case of liquid-propellant rocket engines, most of the actuators used for control functions are valves, regulators, pressure switches, and flow controls. Special computers for automatic control in large engines are also commonly used [5].

anchors: What mechanism is utilized to ensure personnel and equipment safety during equipment malfunctions in rocket engines?
positives: In addition, safety controls are used to protect personnel and equipment in case of malfunctions, and check-out controls make it possible to test the operation of critical components of a rocket engine without actually firing the engine.

anchors: What are the essential components of the engine's initiation process before reaching full operational capacity?
positives: The start sequence of a rocket engine has the purpose of controlling the engine from the moment in which the start signal is given to the full operation of the main stage. This sequence includes the steps of preparation (thrust chamber purging and chill-down of propellant transfer lines), application of start energy (start tanks and turbine spinner), and introduction followed by ignition of the propellants in the main combustion chamber.

anchors: What factors determine whether a start sequence for propellant valves is oxidiser-lead or fuel-lead?
positives: Secondary start sequences may be needed for some subsystems, as is the case with a gas generator or a pre-burner. A start sequence is regulated by means of interlocks, and by monitoring each step of the sequence. The opening sequence of the propellant valves may perform either an oxidiser-lead or a fuel-lead start, depending on the combination of propellants chosen, on the method used to ignite the propellants, and on the method used to cool the thrust chamber.

anchors: What is the range for start delay time in small thrusters, typically measured in seconds?
positives: The start delay time is the time necessary to purge the engine, open the valves, initiate the combustion, and increase the pressure in the combustion chamber to the rated value. This time is usually small (from 0.003 to 0.015 s in small thrusters) for an engine fed by gas under pressure, in which the pressurisation system has to be activated and the ullage volume has to be put under pressure before the start.

anchors: What are the additional time requirements for starting an engine using turbo-pumps compared to a pressure-fed engine?
positives: An engine fed by turbo-pumps requires more time to start (from | to 5 s), because it is necessary not only to execute the operations indicated above for a pressure-fed engine, but also to start a gas generator or a pre-burner, and to increase the speed of the turbo-pumps to a level in which the combustion can be firstly self-sustained and then brought to its full extent. When the combination of propellants used in a rocket engine is not hypergolic, additional time is necessary for the igniter to work and for the control function to confirm the proper operation of the igniter. The ignition methods used for liquid-propellant rocket engines have been discussed in Chap. 2, Sects. 2.7 and 2.8..

anchors: What procedures are included in the shutdown sequence during test firings to ensure safety after combustion?
positives: The shutdown sequence is executed either in normal operating conditions or in cases of emergency. This is done by shutting off the flow to the gas generator (or to the pre-burner) and to the main combustion chamber. In case of test firings, the shutdown sequence also includes purges and flushes for post-firing safety. The control system regulates the valve closing sequence in such a way as to provide a fuel-rich cut-off in the main combustion chamber.

anchors: What sequence do the valves follow when closing, and which valve is prioritized in the shutdown process?
positives: This prevents high picks of temperature and 454 5 Control Systems and Valves results in a smooth and rapid termination of the thrust. The valves close in a fixed sequence. The valve controlling the gas generator or the pre-burner closes first. The pressurisation in the propellant tanks is stopped. The pumps slow down, as a result of the decrease in the gas flow through the turbine. The pressures and the mass flow rates of the propellants decrease quickly and reduce to zero..

anchors: What components determine the initialization, operation, and cessation processes of the three primary engines of the Space Shuttle?
positives: In the three main engines (RS-25) of the Space Shuttle, the characteristics of start, run, and shutdown are established by the combined actions of the main fuel valve, the main oxidiser valve, the oxidiser pre-burner oxidiser valve, the fuel pre- burner oxidiser valve, and the chamber coolant valve. These valves are powered by hydraulic actuators which receive positioning signals from the engine controller, which in turn uses performance data gathered by sensors located throughout the engine.

anchors: What is the purpose of the valves in the propellant flow scheme of the RS-25 engine?
positives: A functional scheme showing the propellant flow through the RS-25 engine and the valves named above is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of Wikimedia [6]..

anchors: What operating conditions change the state of the chamber coolant valve during the engine run phase?
positives: With reference to the preceding figure, the main oxidiser valve, the main fuel valve, and the chamber coolant valve are switched to run schedules during the engine run phase, while the oxidiser pre-burner oxidiser valve and the fuel pre-burner oxidiser valve are switched to closed-loop operations. The run schedule for the main oxidiser valve and for the main fuel valve cause them to simply remain fully open, whereas the run schedule for the chamber coolant valve drives it between half open at 67% thrust (minimum power level) and fully open at 100% thrust and above (in the Space Shuttle main engine, the thrust is variable between the minimum power level or 67% to the full power level or 109%, the rated or 100% value being 2.094 x 10° N in vacuo and 1.667 x 10° N at sea level).

anchors: What role do the oxidiser pre-burner valves play in regulating engine thrust and mixture proportions?
positives: This action maintains the appropriate 5.2 Control Systems for Rocket Engines 455 flow relationships among the several parallel fuel flow paths, as the high-pressure fuel turbo-pump output pressure varies with thrust. During engine run, the oxidiser pre-burner oxidiser valve and the fuel pre-burner oxidiser valve are used as control devices for thrust and mixture ratio. Manipulating the valves affects the output of the pre-burners, the speed of the turbo-pumps, and therefore the propellant flow rates.

anchors: What components are involved in controlling the mixture ratio and thrust in a combustion system?
positives: The fuel pre-burner oxidiser valve is driven alone to maintain mixture ratio in the main combustion chamber, while the oxidiser pre-burner oxidiser valve is driven with the fuel pre-burner oxidiser valve to increase or decrease thrust while maintaining the mixture ratio. The control loops include the controller, the valve actuators, and the transducers which sense the flow rates and the pressure in the main combustion chamber, and therefore the thrust.

anchors: What is the purpose of establishing a fuel lag during the engine shutdown phase?
positives: During the engine shutdown phase, all five valves are switched to shutdown schedules. These schedules ensure a smooth and safe shutdown by establishing a fuel lag. In other words, the oxidiser leaves the combustion chambers ahead of the fuel. This lag creates a fuel-rich and cool shutdown environment [7]..

anchors: What functions are performed by the controller of the engine regarding its operation, checks, and data collection?
positives: The controller of the RS-25 engine provides complete and continuous moni- toring and control of engine operation. In addition, it performs maintenance and start preparation checks, and collects data for historical and maintenance purposes. The controller of the RS-25 engine is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of Boeing-Rocketdyne [7].

positives: eyes Fas Stee oS » Le a + 0 <S tL) jee > 3s, Qe: hat age 7

anchors: What are the five main components included in the electronic package of a controller?
positives: The controller is an electronic package which contains five principal sections:© computer interface section; and e digital computer unit.

anchors: What are the three operational modes of a dual-redundant controller?
positives: Pressure, temperature, pump speed, flow rate, and position sensors supply the input signals. Output signals operate spark igniters, solenoid valves, and hydraulic 456 5 Control Systems and Valves actuators. The controller is dual-redundant, which gives it normal, fail-operate, and fail-safe operational mode capability. Fail-operate mode follows a first failure, and is similar to normal mode, but with a loss of some redundancy.

anchors: What happens to engine controls and functions when the system enters a state of fail-safe operation?
positives: Fail-safe mode follows a second failure. In this mode, engine throttling and mixture ratio control are suspended, the main propellant valves are held fixed in their last commanded position, and the engine is subsequently shutdown pneumatically. The controller provides active and continuous control of the engine thrust and of the mixture ratio in the main combustion chamber through closed-loop control.

anchors: How does the controller adjust the oxidiser valve to maintain the desired thrust in the main combustion chamber?
positives: The controller reads the pressure (equivalent to the thrust) in the main combustion chamber, and compares it to the existing thrust reference signal. It uses the error to drive the oxidiser pre-burner oxidiser valve, which adjusts the thrust and eliminates the error. For the mixture ratio in the main combustion chamber, the controller reads the fuel flow-meter and drives the fuel pre-burner oxidiser valve to adjust the fuel flowing to the main combustion chamber, thus maintaining a mixture ratio o/f = 6.

anchors: What updates the controller instructions to the engine control elements and how frequently does this occur?
positives: In addition to these primary functions, the controller performs engine checkout, limit monitoring, start readiness verification, and engine start and shutdown sequencing. The controller instructions to the engine control elements are updated 50 times per second (every 20 ms). The electronics are mounted on modular boards inside a sealed and pressurised chassis, which is cooled by heat convection through pin fins [7]..

anchors: How can the thrust of a rocket engine be adjusted during the final phase of its flight?
positives: The thrust of a rocket engine is controlled in magnitude by regulating the pressure in the main combustion chamber. Sometimes, a reduction of the thrust magnitude, also known as throttling, is necessary in the last part of the propelled flight of a rocket vehicle. This reduction can be performed by decreasing, either stepwise or continuously, the pressure in the main combustion chamber.

anchors: How can the pressure in the main combustion chamber of turbo-pump-fed rocket engines be decreased through propellant management?
positives: Incase of rocket engines fed by turbo-pumps, the pressure in the main combustion chamber can be reduced by regulating either the mass flow rate of the propellants through the gas generator or the mass flow rate of the hot gas through the turbine. When the first method is used, it is also possible to vary the mixture ratio of the propellants.

anchors: How can the pressure in a rocket's combustion chamber be decreased when using gas-fed engines?
positives: In case of rocket engines fed by gases under pressure, the pressure in the combus- tion chamber can be reduced by regulating the pressures in the main tanks of the propellants.In case of multiple engines arranged in a cluster, thrust control can be performed by shutting off one or more engines of the cluster.

anchors: What method is described for regulating thrust in a rocket engine that uses turbo-pumps?
positives: The examples of thrust regulation considered in Sect. 5.1 concern the case of a rocket engine fed by gases under pressure and the case of a rocket engine fed by turbo-pumps. In the second case, the thrust has been controlled in magnitude by using a valve regulating the value of the mass flow rate in the gas generator, and therefore the power delivered by the turbine. 5.3. Control of Thrust Magnitude 457 The example given below concerns thrust regulation performed by varying the flow of the propellants.

positives: The following, figure, re-drawn from [3], illustrates the scheme of a closed-loop control system based on flow variation. anchors: What device measures the pressure in the combustion chamber and indicates the thrust magnitude?
positives: In the present case, the regulation is based on two valves which determine the resistances encountered by the two different propellants in their respective lines towards the combustion chamber. A chamber pressure transducer senses the pressure Pc in the combustion chamber, which is used as an indicator of the thrust magnitude. The output signal y of the chamber pressure transducer is fed back as a secondary input to the thrust throttle control computer, which compares the signal y with its primary input, which is the reference signal r.

anchors: What is the relationship between the error calculation and the regulation of propellant control valves in a thrust throttle control system?
positives: The error e = r — y is used to drive the thrust throttle control actuator, which in turn regulates the control valves of the propellants in such a way as to reduce the error..

anchors: How is the thrust adjustment achieved in the RS-25 engine?
positives: In the RS-25 engine, throttling is accomplished by varying the output of the pre- burners, thus varying the speed of the high-pressure turbo-pumps, and therefore the mass flow rates of the propellants (liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen). The mixture ratio of the propellants in the main combustion chamber is o/f = 6.032. This value is maintained by varying the fuel flow rate around the oxidiser flow rate [7].

anchors: What effect does limiting oxidiser flow to pre-burners have on the temperature at the turbine inlet?
positives: In other words, restricting the oxidiser flow to the pre-burners causes the turbine inlet temperature to decrease. 458 5 Control Systems and Valves 5.4 Control of Propellant Mixture Ratio.

anchors: What method can enhance the accuracy of propellant measurement in a rocket engine's open-loop control system?
positives: An open-loop control system of the mixture ratio of the propellants in a rocket engine can be obtained by installing calibration orifices of proper size in the propellant lines. Further refinements are possible by weighing accurately the propellants loaded in the tanks, by using orifices of adjustable (rather than fixed) size in case of storable fluids, in order to regulate the size of the orifices just before take-off, and by installing valves at the pump inlet of engines fed by turbo-pumps, in order to compensate for effects induced by accelerations acting on the fluid mass.

anchors: What mechanism is used to adjust valves and protect pumps based on changes in fluid pressure due to varying accelerations?
positives: In the last manner, an increase or decrease in pressure in the fluids due to variable accelerations is sensed and fed back to a closed-loop control system, which regulates gradually the valves and also protects the pumps..

anchors: What is the role of a control computer in managing the mixture ratio within a closed-loop system?
positives: In certain cases, it is necessary to perform a continuous control of the mixture ratio by using a closed-loop system. In such cases, Huzel and Huang [3] suggest the control scheme shown in the following figure.CONTROL = 1 CONTROL COMPUTER FUEL FLOW, Yep (ality Xe pli m FLOWMETER a VALVE VERNIER VALVE POSITION ACTUATOR OXIDISER FLOW FLOWMETER to

anchors: What is the role of the mixture ratio control oxidiser valve Vernier position actuator in the control system described?
positives: The control system illustrated in the preceding figure has two flow-meters which sense continuously the mass flow rates m, and m, of the propellants. The mixture ratio feedback signal (tit, /my ) , is compared in a computer with areference command signal (rit,/ri), and the resulting error (ri,/riv), is fed to a mixture ratio control oxidiser valve Vernier position actuator. This actuator, in turn, commands the oxidiser control valve, which varies the mass flow rate 7, of the oxidiser, in such a way as to correct the error..

anchors: What are the two types of flow-meters used to measure fluid flow and how do they differ in measurements?
positives: A flow-meter is a device which measures either the volume flow rate g (m?/s) or the mass flow rate 7 (kg/s) of a fluid which passes through it. A volumetric flow- meter (such as a positive displacement flow-meter) measures the volume flow rate q = Av of a fluid stream which passes through a cross-sectional area A (m7) at a velocity v (m/s). A velocity flow meter (such as a magnetic, turbine, ultrasonic, and 5.4 Control of Propellant Mixture Ratio 459 vortex shedding and fluidic flow-meter) measures the velocity v of a fluid stream to determine the volume flow rate g.

anchors: How can the mass flow rate be calculated if the volume flow rate and fluid density are provided?
positives: When the volume flow rate q is known, the mass flow rate 72 results from 1 = pq, where p (kg/m*) is the density of the fluid in the given conditions..

anchors: What is the shape of the hub in the turbine-type flow-meter discussed?
positives: A turbine-type flow-meter having a hemispherical hub is illustrated in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [8].Rotor nw ~ WV WEAN Shaft supports a | | ol eee ciiaaaii stralgonaes7 aay ZY

anchors: What is the relationship between the angular velocity of a rotor and the output signal frequency in a turbine-type flow-meter?
positives: A turbine-type flow-meter is a device in which the entire flow stream turns a bladed rotor at a speed proportional to the volume flow rate of the fluid, and which generates or modulates an output signal, whose frequency is proportional to the angular velocity of the rotor. As shown in the preceding figure, the fluid passing through the flow-meter impinges on the blades of a turbine, which are free to rotate about an axis along the central line of the turbine housing.

anchors: What effect does a blade sweeping through a magnetic field within a pickoff coil have on electrical signal generation?
positives: A permanent magnet placed within the windings of a pickoff coil generates a magnetic field. An electrical cycle is generated by each blade which sweeps through the magnetic field present in the fluid passage..

anchors: What type of scheme is utilized for managing propellant consumption in the system described?
positives: Another flow-meter, based on the Venturi tube, will be described in Sect. 5.7. Further information on several types of flow-meters can be found in [9]. 5.5 Control of Propellant Consumption This type of control is performed by sensors which measure the amount of propellant remaining in the tanks and the unbalance of one of the two propellants with respect to the other. A closed-loop scheme indicated by Huzel and Huang [3] is shown in the following figure.

anchors: What device integrates the outputs from various sensors to manage propellant use in a control system?
positives: 460 5 Control Systems and Valves PROPELLANT USE CONTROL REFERENCE TRANSDUCER f MIXTURE COMPUTER fs COMPUTER TRANSDUCER ® ELECTRIC SUMMING JUNCTION D> ELECTRIC AMPLIFIER.

anchors: What signals from sensors are summed to compare with the control reference signal in the propellant management system?
positives: This control system measures continuously the residual masses my and m, of the two propellants by using sensors placed in the respective tanks. The transducer output signals yy and y, corresponding to these masses are summed, and the signal resulting from the sum yr + yo is compared with a propellant use control reference signal r which is fed to the propellant use control computer.

anchors: What is the formula for the error signal in relation to the command reference mixture ratio and the output values?
positives: The error signal e = r — (yy + y,) is amplified and then used to modify the command reference mixture ratio signal (rity /m Np which is fed to the mixture ratio control computer.

anchors: What type of devices are utilized to measure the volume of fuel stored within a container, according to a survey conducted?
positives: A survey on the sensors used to determine the amount of propellant contained in a tank has been performed by Dodge [10]. A brief account is given below.

anchors: What type of sensor detects fluid presence by measuring changes in electrical impedance due to the surrounding fluid type?
positives: Sensors detecting the presence of fluids of a given type at given locations in a tank are usually called wet-dry sensors. Most wet-dry sensors are based on a hot wire or an electrical resistance or an electrical impedance element which carries a small current. The presence of a given type of fluid at the sensor location is detected by a change in the electrical impedance of the sensor, which in turn depends on the type of fluid (gas or liquid) around the sensor.

anchors: How can the surrounding medium of a sensor be identified based on changes in current or voltage?
positives: This is because the sensor impedance depends on the amount of heat transfer from the sensor to the surrounding medium, due to the heating caused by the passage of the electric current. The heat transfer is greater when the sensor is surrounded by a liquid. Thus, by measuring a change in current for a constant applied voltage or a change in voltage for a constant applied current, it is possible to detect whether the sensor is in a liquid or in a gas..

anchors: What is the purpose of matching the index of refraction in a laser-based optical sensor for liquid measurement?
positives: Another type of sensor is based on a laser light source incorporated in a prism-like capsule, whose index of refraction is matched to the index of refraction of the liquid contained in a tank. A scheme of this optical sensor is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [10]. 5.5 Control of Propellant Consumption 461 Light source Liquid Gas __ \ == Prism ff Photocell ~

anchors: How does the presence of reflection from a prism indicate the state of a sensor immersed in a gas versus a liquid?
positives: When the sensor is immersed in a gas, as shown on the left-hand side of the preceding figure, the light is reflected off the end of the prism back to a photocell at the light source. By contrast, when the sensor is immersed in a liquid, as shown on the right-hand side of the preceding figure, the light is transmitted through the liquid without reflection off the prism. Thus, the presence or absence of a reflection indicates whether the sensor is dry or wet..

anchors: What types of sensors can identify the surface location of a liquid in a tank or measure the liquid's depth?
positives: Sensors which detect the location of the surface of a liquid in a tank or the depth of this liquid above the sensor are called level sensors. In this category are pressure sensors, ultrasonic sensors, and electrical capacity sensors.

anchors: What factors influence the pressure difference measured by a transducer in a liquid-filled tank?
positives: Pressure sensors cannot be used in weightless conditions, because they measure the pressure head p/(pgo) of the liquid placed above the location of the sensor. A pressure transducer is inserted at the bottom of a gauge line going from the bottom to the top of a tank. A pressure sensor detects the difference of pressure existing between the gas at the top and the liquid at the bottom of the tank. This difference is related to the depth of the liquid when the pressure and the temperature of the substance (liquid or gas) are known..

anchors: How does the acoustic impedance mismatch at the liquid-gas interface affect the behavior of ultrasonic waves in a liquid propellant tank?
positives: Ultrasonic sensors generate an ultrasonic pulse which is transmitted through the liquid propellant contained in a tank. A mismatch of acoustic impedance at the liquid- gas interface generates an echo, which is transmitted back through the liquid to an ultrasonic receiver at the transducer location. The time elapsed between the emission of the pulse and the reception of the echo is related to the depth of liquid above the transducer by the sonic velocity in the liquid.

anchors: What is the principle used by a device that manages propellant to maintain liquid in a specific configuration in low-gravity settings?
positives: A sensor of this type can be used in low- gravity conditions, but the liquid must be maintained in a known configuration above the sensor by a propellant management device based on the principle of capillarity..

anchors: What effect does the surrounding medium have on the propagation speed of torsional waves in a wave guide?
positives: An ultrasonic sensor of another type is a torsional wave guide. In this sensor, the speed of a torsional wave propagating along a wave guide, such as a rod, depends on whether the wave guide is immersed in a liquid or ina gas. The impedance mismatch at the liquid-gas interface generates an echo, which is detected to provide information on the length of the wave guide which is immersed in the liquid.

anchors: What effects does liquid adherence in zero gravity have on sensor accuracy during testing?
positives: However, some tests executed in conditions of zero gravity have shown that the adherence of liquid to portions of the wave guide supposed to be dry degraded seriously the accuracy of the sensor..

anchors: What type of probe is employed in a propellant tank to directly measure mass?
positives: A capacity sensor contained in a propellant tank is shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [11]. 462 5 Control Systems and Valves Inner tube. Outer tube — a f wae: \ . iim S Tank HH WG ~ fi Gas im iY sensing prove \ iS 0 Outer tude  eceeereees |: Mn 7: peueeeeeeee ° 4 H Ay OY \ ( ig! | § HN oN Bel | | 4 few! “ee heed % oe pout (a) Perforated, (0) Nonpertorated. Section O° A capacity probe senses mass directly.

anchors: What occurs to the electric capacity of coaxial tubes when the ratio of liquid to gas in a tank changes?
positives: The sensing probe consists essentially of two coaxial tubes contained in a tank. These tubes, when a voltage is applied to them, act as the plates of an electric condenser, whose capacity changes when the proportion between liquid and gas changes. This is because the liquid and the gas contained in the tank have different values of dielectric constant. In other words, the dielectric medium between the two tubes of the probe is the propellant, in liquid and gaseous state, contained in the tank.

anchors: How does the electrical capacity of a probe relate to the amount of liquid present in a tank?
positives: The total electrical capacity of the probe depends on the level of the liquid which fills it. Thus, the measured electrical capacity of the probe provides information on the mass of liquid in the tank. With a suitable electronic apparatus, the mass of the residual propellant in the tank can be measured continuously. The outer tube of the capacity probe may be perforated or not, as shown in the preceding figure.

anchors: What type of probe was selected for the Centaur launch vehicle to improve measurement accuracy?
positives: A non-perforated probe was chosen for the Centaur launch vehicle, because it provided a better measurement [11]. A propellant management system using electrical capacity probes was also chosen for the J-2 engine in the S-IVB stage, as shown in the following figure, due to the courtesy of NASA [12]. 5.5 Control of Propellant Consumption 463 “A WN Switch Selector LHe Bridge = 45:1 50:1 Mixture Mixture LH, Mass j Ratio Retio Probe Command | Command (Capacitance) to Ground , Loading Summing Computer i.

Valve Position Signal In the S-IVB stage, the propellant management system, in conjunction with the switch selector, controls the mass propellant loading ratio and the engine mixture ratio (liquid oxygen to liquid hydrogen) to ensure balanced consumption of propellant.

anchors: What component regulates the flow of liquid oxygen to the engine during flight operations?
positives: The electrical capacity probes, located in the two tanks, monitor the mass of the propellants. During flight, the electrical capacity probes are not used to control the propellant mixture ratio. The mixture ratio is controlled by switch selector outputs, which are used to operate the propellant utilisation (PU) valve. The PU valve is a rotary valve which controls the quantity of liquid oxygen flowing to the engine.

anchors: What mixture ratio is achieved prior to engine start for the PU valve?
positives: The PU valve is commanded to its null position to obtain an engine mixture ratio (EMR) of 5.0:1 prior to engine start. The PU valve remains at the 5.0:1 position during the first burn. Prior to engine restart (first opportunity), the PU valve is commanded by the switch selector to an EMR of 4.5:1 and remain at this position until approximately 464 5 Control Systems and Valves 2 min of S-IVB burn. Then the PU valve is commanded to its null position (5.0:1) by the switch selector.

anchors: What happens to the engine mixing ratio if the restart occurs during the second opportunity?
positives: However, if the S-IVB restart is delayed to the second opportunity, the EMR is shifted from 4.5:1 to 5.0:1 by the switch selector at about the time in which the engine reaches 90% thrust [12]..

anchors: What issues can arise when using an electrical capacity probe in low-gravity environments?
positives: An electrical capacity probe depends on the liquid being settled, and therefore can only be used for gauging during periods of thrusting [10]. In principle, an electrical capacity probe might be used in low-gravity conditions if the liquid configuration is controlled by propellant management devices. However, in such conditions, capillary forces in the annular gap between the walls of the probe would cause the liquid meniscus location to differ from the liquid level in the tank, and thus cause an inaccurate reading, which may be small and could be compensated for.

anchors: What phenomenon caused an inaccurate low liquid level warning during the initial Lunar Module landing on the Moon?
positives: Depending on the design, the probe can also be sensitive to liquid motions such as occurred with the first landing of the Lunar Module on the Moon, for which non-linear sloshing lowered the effective level of the liquid within the gauge to the point that a premature low liquid level warning was given [10]..

anchors: What method estimates the amount of propellant left in a tank by comparing used quantity to the initial load?
positives: In the absence of a specific measurement system, the quantity of propellant remaining in a tank can be estimated by determining the consumption of the propel- lants which have already been used in comparison with the quantity initially loaded in the tanks. This method is commonly called bookkeeping. Some sensors and devices are used in the bookkeeping method, either separately or in conjunction. They are: e flow-meters or Venturi-meters in the lines between the tanks and the main.

anchors: What devices are used to quantify propellant flow rates by assessing pump pressures along with engine thrust calibrations?
positives: combustion chamber or the gas generator to measure the flow rates of thee sensors which determine the flow rates of the propellants by measuring their pressures in the pumps in conjunction with the performance curves of the pumps; and© calibrations of engine thrust versus propellant flow rate and tank pressure. anchors: What limitations affect the accuracy of the bookkeeping technique when monitoring propellant usage in engines, especially as depletion approaches?
positives: sensors are required for the bookkeeping method. This method can only be used during periods of engine thrusting, and its accuracy is limited by the accumula- tion over time of the errors committed in estimating the propellant consumption, in particular near the point of propellant depletion. In addition, the bookkeeping method cannot detect leaks.

anchors: What parameters are used to assess the consumption of propellant based on vehicle acceleration and engine thrust?

positives: © measuring the decay of pressure in the ullage spaces, in case of tanks which are initially pressurised, as the liquids are drained from their tanks and the ullage spaces increase. 5.6 Control of Thrust Direction 465 5.6 Control of Thrust Direction Several methods used to control the direction of the thrust vector in a rocket vehicle have been discussed in Chap. 2, Sect. 2.2, as far as they can affect the design of the thrust chamber of a rocket engine.

anchors: What mechanism is commonly used to control thrust vector in liquid-propellant rocket engines, and what is a benefit of using this method?
positives: The present section is meant to describe in further depth the method of controlling the thrust vector by using a gimbal mechanism acting on either the nozzle or the engine assembly. This method is the most used in liquid- propellant rocket engines, due to its reliability and performance.
